This is one of our weekly sessions. Beginners' hour starts at 7:00 with instruction on basic footwork and formations, allowing everyone to participate in some fun social dances. From about 8:00 until 9:15, we have a Social Class - the focus is on more experienced dancers and complex dances, but beginners are encouraged to stay and watch, and participate in some of the simpler dances.


Beginners are always welcome, no partner necessary. (In fact, you will be encouraged to dance with more experienced dancers rather than with other beginners.)

The $7.00 fee per person for each class covers the cost of renting the room and paying the teacher. First-time attendees and dues-paying members pay only $5. We do not want price to be an obstacle for anyone attending class. Beginners have the option of purchasing a coupon booklet (good for 10 classes) for $30. Full-time students can always pay only $3 to attend. If these options don't work for you, please let me or one of the teachers know and other arrangements can be made.

Please don't be discouraged by the lack of RSVPs - many of our members do not belong to Meetup and so do not RSVP here. There will definitely be a crowd of dancers present!

results.description:
These days you hear a lot about languages with fancy type systems and some of the outlandish things possible to do in them. These include feats such as building a C compiler which is guaranteed to produce correct code, synthesizing fast and correct data structures from specifications, and even verifying the correctness of distributed algorithms.

This all sounds incredible but the learning curve for these tools is high, in part because there are so many moving parts! There's an interpreter (or 3), a tactic compiler, a tactic engine, various compilers for code extraction, and dozens of other subsystems underlying a modern proof assistant. In this talk we'll walk through a very simple proof assistant called miniprl to see how some of these components might be implemented.

Participants are expected to know a bit about (statically typed) functional programming to follow along with the code but since this is mostly a talk about implementation, we'll avoid any heavy dependencies on dependent type theory or similar. By the end, you will hopefully be in a much better position to learn an industrial strength proof assistant or even write your own toy versions.
results.name: Building a Proof Assistant

results.description:
If you've never explored the Morton Valley Trail in Boyce-Mayview Park, you'll be in for a treat!  It's beautiful to walk through and has been rated one of the best walking trails in the city!   We will walk at a slow to moderate pace for about an hour.  Wear waterproof hiking shoes/ boots and dress accordingly to walking on trails that may be a bit muddy.  Bring a water bottle and snack if you'd like.  

Directions from US Rt. 19 (Washington Road)


Proceed south on US Rt. 19 (Washington Road) to Boyce Road which is 3.0 miles south of South Hills Village Shopping Center (at Ft. Couch Road). Turn right onto Boyce Road and proceed 0.5 miles to the intersection with Morton Road on the right. Turn right and then immediately left into the garden plot parking area (indicated by “A” on the map).

If the gate to the garden plots is closed or as an alternate, continue on Boyce Road another 0.6 miles to the paved turn-off just before Ardolino's Pizza on the right 

Another alternate entrance is on Mayview Road. Continue on Boyce Road to the intersection with Mayview Road (next traffic light) and turn right. Proceed 1.1 miles on Mayview Road to the railroad track crossing (indicated by “C” on the map). Park in the small triangle of land on the west side of Mayview Road bordered by the railroad tracks and Chartiers Creek. (There is room for only 2 or 3 cars.) Cross Mayview Road and enter the park through the gate to the wetlands.

Directions from Interstate 79

Take Bridgeville exit (No. 54) from I-79. At the end of the exit ramp, turn right onto Millers Run Road (PA Route 50) and proceed to the traffic light at the T-instersection with Washington Pike in front of the Exxon station. Turn right onto Washington Pike and drive for for 2.1 miles to the intersection with Boyce Road. Turn right onto Boyce and proceed 1.4 miles to the traffic light at the intersection with Mayview Road.

If you want to enter the park through the wetlands, turn left on to Mayview road and drive for 1.1 miles to the railroad track crossing (indicated by “C” on the map). Park in the small triangle of land on the west side of Mayview Road bordered by the railroad tracks and Chartiers Creek. (There is room for only 2 or 3 cars.) Cross Mayview Road and enter the park through the gate to the wetlands.

To use the Boyce Road entrances to the park, continue on Boyce Road for another 0.5 mile to Ardolino's Pizza on the left. There is a paved turn off and parking area just past the pizza shop.

You can also use the garden plot parking area at the intersection with Morton Road. Proceed another 0.6 mile to the intersection with Morton Road on the left. Turn left and then another immediate left into the parking area (indicated by “A” on the map).
results.how_to_find_us: We will meet at the paved turn off just before  Ardolino's Pizza on Boyce Road.  See detailed directions below

results.description:
Get Heard! Get Noticed! Get Leads! (TM)

Hosted by: Valerie Rose of Northwood Reality Services and co-hosted by Cathy Gipson of Style Dots.

This is an informal networking event, open to any business woman who would like to increase her business contacts or clients in the Washington area.

Things to bring:

- 10-20 business cards or marketing material

- cash for your lunch check

- $5 meeting fee (non members only)

Be prepared to do a 60 second commercial and provide the following information.

- Your goal for attending or 
- What is a good referral for you or 
- Name one product or service that you offer that will specifically help small business owners or business professionals.

AGENDA

1:00 pm - attendees arrive, reviews menu, gives the server their drink order, and open networking: everyone stands up to introduce oneself to others and pass their business card.

1:15 pm - server takes lunch order and the sign in sheet is passed around

1:30 pm - 60 sec. commercials begin

2:00 pm - each person gives a testimony or referral for someone attending the lunch

2:30 pm - Premier member does a 5 min. company presentation

2:35 pm - WSBA announcements from Debi/Susan

2:45 pm - lunch has ended. Open networking is welcomed.

Please RSVP if you plan to attend this lunch. If your schedule becomes free the day of the lunch, then you may attend without an RSVP. This lunch is subject to cancellation when the lunch has 3 or less RSVPs. Lunch cancellation policy.

If you are not a WSBA member and would like to attend as a guest, please contact Kimfitnesschic at <a>[masked]</a>

If you have an interest in becoming a General member ($50/year) or Premier member ($100/year) of WSBA, please contact <a>Debi Arnett </a>or arnett.debi at whosyourbrother.com

If you are unable to attend, then please change your RSVP. Any non member that RSVPs and does not attend will be removed from this site.

results.description:
Welcome to the first Pittsburgh Identity & Access Management user group meetup! Are you an IAM professional looking to network and learn more about the industry? Please join us for food, drinks and technical content.


Networking, best practices and an open exchange of ideas between IAM professionals is the only agenda. Come prepared to discuss ideas and find out best practices from some of the leaders in the IAM community.

After introductory networking, the agenda for the meeting will include:

- Ashley Shaner, IT Analyst Information Security at Erie Insurance - Role based access control: Failing forward

- Eric Anderson, Information Security Architect at Blue Cross/Blue Shield of IL/TX/NM/OK/MT - On the hurdles of disparate identity sources, organizational inertia, and how to show the business material gains in efficiency and information accuracy.

- Bring Your Own Challenges: Opportunity for members to bring up their own “IAM challenges” that they want to share with the group for discussion: Cloud migration? Shadow IT? Multifactor Authentication?

Please recommend this event to your IAM friends and colleagues.

I request a $10 fee for the beginner class -- payable at the beginning of the class.  If that is a problem for you, just let me know.  There is no charge for the weekly meetups ... only the classes.

results.name: Mah Jong 101 - intro for beginners

results.description:
Join us on Tuesdays for American Mah Jong! Folks begin arriving around 5PM, and play begins table by table as soon as we have three or four players plus a set.  (We usually have 3-5 tables.)  By 6:15 or so, most players have arrived. We rotate among the tables... at the end of each game, East walks around to see if another table is close to the end of their game, so that two players can swap places.   At the other end of the evening... play must end by 9PM when Panera closes.  Tables begin wrapping up play any time after 8:15 or so.


If you have never played, or if you have not played for a very long time, we highly recommend that you take a Mah Jong 101 beginner class before playing with us - beginner classes are offered every few months.  Mah jong is a wonderful game, but it's hard to learn by just watching others play!


Please order your 2015 card from the National Mah Jongg League, here: http://www.nationalmahjonggleague.org/ Amazon.com also carries the cards. Note that you want the NMJL card, and no other! (There are some colorful alternatives out there.. but we play NMJL card and rules.)

Experienced players -- please bring your cards and please bring a set if you have one.

Please do not bring any outside food or beverages into Panera! Instead, please plan to buy *something* from Panera, even if it's just a beverage or a cookie, to support their willingness to host us.
results.how_to_find_us: Hard to miss us, look for the Mah Jong sets!

results.description:
Networking isn't easy, it isn't always fun. In the professional world it's a must. Especially for women! And we can't afford to wait to 'network' until we need our network. We must nurture, grow and embrace our opportunities and connections.

But who am I kidding. When we, women, chose to attend a networking event it means trade-offs. What on our to-do lists will get bumped so we can focus on our needs? Then to attend the event, maybe grab a bite if offered, and then yet attempt to do as much as we can on our to-do list because we know it all starts again the next day.

That's why I propose we network over dinner! It's a new thought I'm hoping to run with, at various locations throughout the greater Pittsburgh area to bring together women working in the digital arenas of today's business culture. I hope you'll join me!

Agenda:


• 5:30 - 6pm: Open networking, arrive at your convenience. Mingle over beverages. 

• 6 - 7pm: Dinner. Enjoy active discussions at tables with 4-5 fellow, digitally ambitious women.

• 7 - 7:30pm: On with the night and our to-do lists

Details

The inaugural, kick-off, dinner will be held April 12, 2016 at Asiago's Tuscan Italian, located on the North Shore, between PNC Park and Heinz Field. Plenty of parking, near by, and easy access to the T station on the North Short.

All ladies in attendance will receive an individual bill. Feel free to come and leave as your need.
results.how_to_find_us: We'll be in the party room, behind the bar and wall of wine
results.name: Networking + dinner

results.description:
Abstract

The Build Windows conference was from March 30th to April 1st. Join us on April 12th as we recap the events of this conference with Microsoft's regional director, Mike Snell. We will talk about some of the great stuff that came out for developers as well as the clear focus on Azure, IoT, and other forms of interacting with users.

Speaker

Mike Snell has twenty years of experience leading teams to create software for great clients. Mike has led CEI’s Solutions Delivery group for close to 10 years. This group includes architects, developers, and project managers in Pittsburgh, Philadelphia, and the Washington DC area. Mike and his team have delivered 100s of projects across nearly every industry. They specialize in enterprise software, commercial development, mobile applications, developer training, and project-based mentoring.

Mike holds the distinction of Microsoft Regional Director (RD). Microsoft Regional Directors are architects, developers, trainers, and other professionals who provide a vital link between Microsoft and the developer community. Mike is one of approximately 120 individuals to have earned this honorable distinction from Microsoft. Mike is also a published author in the software development space. He has written eight books to-date including the Visual Studio Unleashed series and various Microsoft Training Kits. He has also contributed articles to multiple publications. Mike also speaks at many industry events and group meetings.

Sponsor

This month's meeting is sponsored by Randstad Technologies.

https://www.randstadusa.com/technologies/
results.name: What I learned at Build 2016

results.description:
Our monthly meetup allows people to do (meditative style) shamanic journey work together to have and share experiences, grow together, and have a sense of community with others engaged in their own spiritual growth and self healing. We request a $5 donation from those who can give to cover costs of the meetup, but you are more than welcome to come even if you are unable to donate. Each month we set an alter, welcome in the energies, share a journey, and release the energy. You are welcome to participate in the journey planned or to do your own journey work during the time we are journeying as a group. After the journey we have a quiet time for people to record their experiences if they choose to do so and then you are given an opportunity to share if you would like to (sharing is never required). You are recommended to have basic journey skills prior to the meetup as this is not a 101 class (if you would like to host a 101 class, get in touch with me to arrange it!).

The space is set, cleansed and protected before people arrive. You will be given a blessing and cleansing when you arrive prior to entering the space. Then the schedule proceeds as follows:

7pm door opens. If you come between 7:10 and 7:35 please wait in the waiting area while we build the alter.

7-7:25 alter building (feel free to bring something that reflects one of the elements or your ancestors if you wish to)

7:35 Door is locked, first journey starts

7:35-8:30, however many journeys the group feels like doing that fits in the time span. We occasionally go longer until 9, but you will be welcome to pass on from the group at a break at 8:30 if we choose to do this and you have that need.

I am again going to diffuse appropriate oils for this meetup as it is still a bit dry for the smoke and folks are really lovin' on the oils! If you have an allergy or sensitivity, please let me know so I can plan accordingly.

This day on the Aztec calendar combines the energy of rabbit and death. Of course, on European calendars, this is a time of water and the sacrificed guide. For Christian teachings, the time of Christ's sacrifice is just passing over (the date of the "last supper" on the Jewish calendar this year is May 23, which celebrates the memorial of the Passover, another time of sacrifice and death for the fertility and prosperity of a people). You see how the energies across the world are recognizing the same cycles.

The energy on this a perfect time to explore our own personal mythos around sacrifice for the greater good and the religious idea that holding something sacred can result in spiritual experiences of self-transcendence. It is also a strong day for water and moon energy, which is useful for communicating with nature, the cycles of time, seasons and energy, and spiritually transformative forces.

I'm really looking forward to exploring this energy with you.

Hope to see you there! Feel free to message me with questions or concerns at [masked]
results.name: Monthly Journey Group: April Meetup

In our next meet up we will have a fun and interactive session on ways to communicate with our guides easily and how to better understand how they speak to you.

Specifically we will move up to the next vibration and discuss our Runners. These are spirit guides that run ahead and help you find things that you’ve lost or misplaced or connect you to things that you seek, such as apartments, homes, items on sale, or even parking spaces on a busy street.

Next we will discuss our Helper Guides who help us gain the knowledge and skills about anything we need help with.  They do this by sharing the knowledge and skills they learned while in human form and are committed to sharing them with you before they move on to higher frequencies.

Finally we will talk about one of the most beautiful groups of guides you will ever connect with called our Healer Guides. These guides let us know when our choices are not in alignment with our health and well-being. When invoked they work with doctors and healers in the physical realm to help them become extraordinary  healers. 

If you’re in the healing profession you won’t want to miss this meet up.

Look forward to seeing you at our next meet up!

Blessings,

results.description: One of growing spiritual movements today, and the current focus of my spiritual interest, is Direct Pointing. There is new interest in this ancient technique for direct experience. Today this approach is exemplified by Loch Kelly in his book Shift into Freedom - The Science and Practice of Open-hearted Awareness. Kelly, a meditation teacher and psychotherapist, offers a way to enter into 'open-hearted awareness' by using verbal pointers to lead a seeker into a direct experience of Awareness.  At the meeting we will present an overview of the Direct Pointing approach based Loch Kelly’s book and we’ll do some of the “pointing” exercises. A sample of the book is available to members in the Files section found above under More in the top page menu. See you there. Mike.

results.description:
Join us for a 2-hour session of indoor volleyball open gym! You'll get a ton of playing time in a well-organized event. Our host will check players in, divide players into teams, and make sure that everything runs smoothly. All you have to do is show up ready to play!

Pricing:

• $7 - RSVP online and pay in advance because you know you are attending. (online rsvp closes at 4:30 pm!)

• $8.50 - RSVP and pay 50 cents via PayPal and $8 cash at the event if you are pretty sure you are attending (note the 50 cents is non-refundable)

• $10 - Show up and play - be sure to check online to make sure there is room!

What to Wear: We are playing indoors on a rubberized all-sport surface. Most players wear volleyball-specific shoes, but gym shoes are also allowed. Please bring your shoes and change into them at the facility. This will help keep the floor clean of dirt and water.

What to Expect: Show up early! The games will begin at the time posted for this event. Players can start checking in with the event host as early as 15 minutes before the scheduled start time. If a court is available, you may begin warming up before the event begins. We limit play to 42 players per evening, which is 3 teams of 7 players per court. If we have 3 teams on a court, winners stay once and then shuffle out so everyone gets to play. If less people are in attendance, we divide based on who is there and mix things up half way through the session.

Level of Play: This event is open to all levels of play. We do our best to create even teams so that games are well-matched. Our ideal scenario is having one court of higher skilled players and one court of more recreational players. There are no referees, so players need to play with sportsmanship and make their own calls. We aim to make everyone feel welcome at these events.

Facility Information: Monroeville Sports Center is located at 855 Macbeth Drive in Monroeville. Parking should be ample in the free lot.

Minimum number of players and playing formats. This event needs a minimum of 12 people (not including the host) signed up before the start of the event in order to run. An email notification will be sent if we cancel. Refunds or credits will be issued if we cancel the event. Sign up early to encourage more people to sign up!!

Do Your Part! Help us keep an accurate guest count! If you RSVP, we're counting on you to be there. If you change your mind about playing or your guest count changes, please update your RSVP. No-Shows will be marked on your account. If space is tight, we hold RSVP spots 10 minutes into advertised start and then open spots to walk-ups.

Requirements to play: This is an adult volleyball group. You must be 19 older. Males and females of all skill levels are welcome to play. There is no required gender ratio. Players are expected to conduct themselves with good sportsmanship.

What's included in the price? Your payment helps to cover the rental costs, the hourly pay for your event host, and ensures a well-organized event.

Questions? Post your question in the comments section of this meetup and the event host or one of our organizers will reply. You can also message the organizers directly through meetup. Or, give us a call M-F 8:00am-12:30pm:[masked]-7130.

results.description: We begin the science portion of this series by stating a simple fact: for most of us, life is seemingly always in turmoil. But would you believe that underlying it all is actually organization and order? There is a scientific concept that is a perfect place to start our journey - chaos theory - which holds within it the scientific backing for Matthew 17:20 ("Faith the size of a mustard seed can move a mountain."), and the best way man has ever figured out how to handle chaos - oxygen. In this group we will process fascinating concepts such as the butterfly effect and fractals as well as the science behind Buddha's best advice - take a deep breath!

results.description:
This park is located on Beadling Road in Mt. Lebanon. This will be an easy hike with a few good hills thrown in to get the heart rate going!

Though you’ll find many birds there, the park is named in honor of Lieutenant Thomas A. Bird, Jr., U.S. Marine, who was the first Mt. Lebanon resident to give his life in the Vietnam War. The park was dedicated to honor him and all of Mt. Lebanon’s Vietnam Veterans in 1967.

It's a very pretty park and it's great for kids and dogs, so bring them along if you'd like! (they do have to be leashed there---the dogs, not the kids ;)

results.description:
Come on out and learn why so many plants deemed "invasive" are actually here for a reason.

Plants like Japanese Knotweed, Multiflora Rose, and Garlic Mustard are full of vitamins and nutrients, and can be used as a free food source!


Having worked in health food stores for around 12 years, I see many packaged vitamins and supplements that are actually based off of these very plants.


Stop out to find out exactly how they are edible, how to utilize them for food and medicine, and why they are important to the region and ecosystem!

results.description:
Let's go to Social for drinks and dinner at Social in Bakery Square.

Social is awesome because not only are they physically accessible for people with mobility impairments, they have braille menus available for people who need them! What better way to say Thank You! than by having a meal there with friends?

I currently have a reservation for 15, though I can increase that if needed. That said, given the limitation, we would ask that people only RSVP as a yes if they are definitely going to be able to come.

A few things:

* Please bring some cash - they said a maximum of 6 checks for the whole table, and I'm not sure how strict they are about it.

* Please RSVP by Tuesday, April 12, so I can give an accurate head count to the restaurant the day of the event. If you say yes and then can't come, we ask you to please change your RSVP to no for ease of planning.

* Please let us know by April 6 if you need a sign language interpreter so we know to hire one for the event. We will have small cards available for people to fill out to give to store managers explaining why we chose to eat there that day. If anybody wants to print up their own copy to have ready in advance, you can find the files here: https://www.dropbox.com/sh/2ciyxn4hcfr4wpo/AACwGFgdR9cezCArlCpk5Wt0a?dl=0

For more information about Social, check out their website here: http://www.bakerysocial.com/

results.description:
WHAT IS "Beginner Plus"?

On Second Wednesdays, we play familiar tunes at a slower pace. You’ve already taken some lessons. Now it’s time to talk about some basic strums, alternate chord fingering, and how to move and slide between chords. Learn tricks, cheats and other valuable info geared to newer players and also to those who just like to hang out and play with a group. 

“West of the Mississippi” PLAYLIST/ April 12, 2016

365 YELLOW BOOK

Buffalo Gals  40 

She’ll be Comin Round the Mountain  p 267

Deep In the Heart of Texas  64 

She'll Be Coming Round The Mountain 209 

These Boots Are Made For Walkin'  232 

Home On the Range 110 

Shenandoah  208 

Red River Valley 195 

Rawhide 194

She’ll be Comin Round the Mountain  p 267

On the Road Again  182 

Your Cheatin’ Heart 281/ A

Jackson 139/D

Hounddog  111

366 BLUE BOOK/ will pass out copies

Don't Fence Me In   85

I'm an Old Cowhand 174

Streets of Laredo(HERE)

Ghost Riders In the Sky  (HERE)

Yellow Rose of Texas, copy     (The Yellow Rose of Texas is not a flower. Rose is a “she,” a servant  named Emily West, indentured to Colonel James Morgan, who fought in the Texas war of independence from Mexico. INFO thanks to Kathy for her Google-ing)

===========

Wanna Little Homework?


Below are basic chords. It's a good idea to get comfortable with them. Notice how many chord changes take barely a slide of your fingers. Sometimes a finger just stays in place...

Key of C:  C  D7,   C    F,   F   G7,  G7   Am,  G7    C

Key of G:  G    D7,  G   C,  C  D7,  the barred D7,  Em  G   Em,    D7    G

Key of F:  F    G7,    F    Bb,  F  C7,  Bb  C7,  C7  Dm,  F  Dm ,  C7    F

Bring: Ukulele, music stand, tuner, music "TheDaily Ukulele - 365 Songs For Better Living" by Liz and Jim Beloff. Feel free to bring snacks n'at to share. We’ll have fun, and drink a little wine, too.  Marlene is host-leader. You’re invited.

Hi All,

We're meeting at 8:00 at the tennis court of Cranberry Community park and will play 2 hours or more.
If there are some people who want to play some tennis, please bring your racket and let's play together.

This is the event for all levels.
If you have any questions, please let me know.

Here is some guide I want to share with members. 


 ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
 TENNIS MEETUP RULES

1. Always RSVP before you come to the event. This helps in organizing and for reserving the courts. Note, without RSVP you may not have a spot.

2. If you RSVPed "Yes" and later decided to not come, please change the RSVP to "No" so the first member on the waiting list can get your spot.

3. Members are expected to arrive on time and stay for the duration. If you expect to be late more than 15 minutes, please send a text message to the posted organizer's phone number.

4. We will practice and always play a game - doubles or singles, depending on the number of members who come to the event.

5. The organizer will try to pair the teams based on skill levels but this may not always be possible and the pairing may be on a first-come-first-serve basis.

6. If a member is on the waiting list they can still come, however they may have to wait for courts to become available.
  ----------------------------------------------------------------------------

  Jason,

results.description:
$79 per player pricing - what a great deal for a 7 week season!

Sign up as an individual - great way to meet new friends! - with a group of friends - or as a full team. 

What's included in the price? 

• 6 regular season games plus playoffs (all teams qualify)

• Paid referee

•  Teams play 2 twenty minute games each week


• Championship prize for winning team: Choice of customized apparel or trophy!

• Food/Drink specials at sponsor bar

Format  
  6v6= wide open offensive games. LOTS of fun.


When are we playing?  
This league plays a round robin regular season with game times at 10 pm. A full season schedule and standings will be available on sportsmonster.net by week 2. 

Playing surface and what to wear:  
Field Turf. Athletic shoes are required. Teams must wear same-colored, permanent numbered shirts.

Level of competition:

Recreational

 - If you and or your team are looking for a good time and aren't the best football player(s) out there but love the game then this is your league. This level is set for those players who didn't play in college and maybe played some high school or your just overall athletic and want to play ball. You can even have a mixture of good players and beginners, but this level is set for our recreational players. 

These leagues are happening! Don't see a bunch of people registered here? Don't worry! Many people and teams register directly on our sportsmonster.net website instead. So go ahead and sign up to play! 

Full Team Registration
*Want to Register as a Full Team? -- If you want to register a full team, you can do so but roster size MUST be at least 8. And yes, you can pay for all of them here. If players are signing up on their own, have each player/group be sure to reference one another so we know to place you together -- see questions when you RSVP. 

When will I find out which team I'm on? 
Once a team is formed, a roster will be provided to all the players and we ask someone from the team to volunteer to act as captain to ensure a full team is showing up each week and a positive vibe is maintained throughout the season. 

Don't want to pay online here? You may register through sportsmonster.net and pay by check or money order but you will be paying full value as presented on that site. 

If you have any questions please don't hesitate to ask. 
Call:[masked]
E-mail: [masked]

All registrations made through this Meetup event agree to the terms and conditions found on sportsmonster.net.

results.description:
This is a big question for us as Entrepreneurs - What Should I charge my customers and clients for my products or services?

It brings up a lot of our money fears and beliefs and even can cause us to question our self-worth. 

Host Joy Bufalini is going to lead this topic with lots of discussion and insights so we can discover what is right for our particular business. We'll uncover the money beliefs that underlie our practical concerns and doubts. 

We will look at questions such as:

*How do I know what is the right amount to charge?

*How will customers respond if I raise my prices?

*Will other people in my life who don't understand my business think I'm greedy or selfish?

*What should I do when I'm nervous about asking someone to pay me?

And we will look at these considerations:

*Do you do too much for free?

*Is bartering your services with someone okay?

*Should you give friends or family a discount?

*Are you clear about the scope and sequence of your services for which they are paying you?


Whew! This is going to be challenging and inspiring!

I'm excited for you to join us. RSVP NOW. 

Just a reminder that this group is different from other women's groups that are primarily geared towards networking. We exchange business cards in order to keep in touch, but this is not a venue for recruiting customers or clients. Thank you for respecting the purpose of this specific group. 


Visitors are welcome! We are a friendly and supportive group and look forward to meeting you.
results.name: What should I charge for my products or services? Practical $$ questions.

results.description:
If you've never explored the Morton Valley Trail in Boyce-Mayview Park, you'll be in for a treat!  It's beautiful to walk through and has been rated one of the best walking trails in the city!   We will walk at a slow to moderate pace for about an hour.  Wear waterproof hiking shoes/ boots and dress accordingly to walking on trails that may be a bit muddy.  Bring a water bottle and snack if you'd like.  

Directions from US Rt. 19 (Washington Road)


Proceed south on US Rt. 19 (Washington Road) to Boyce Road which is 3.0 miles south of South Hills Village Shopping Center (at Ft. Couch Road). Turn right onto Boyce Road and proceed 0.5 miles to the intersection with Morton Road on the right. Turn right and then immediately left into the garden plot parking area (indicated by “A” on the map).

If the gate to the garden plots is closed or as an alternate, continue on Boyce Road another 0.6 miles to the paved turn-off just before Ardolino's Pizza on the right 

Another alternate entrance is on Mayview Road. Continue on Boyce Road to the intersection with Mayview Road (next traffic light) and turn right. Proceed 1.1 miles on Mayview Road to the railroad track crossing (indicated by “C” on the map). Park in the small triangle of land on the west side of Mayview Road bordered by the railroad tracks and Chartiers Creek. (There is room for only 2 or 3 cars.) Cross Mayview Road and enter the park through the gate to the wetlands.

Directions from Interstate 79

Take Bridgeville exit (No. 54) from I-79. At the end of the exit ramp, turn right onto Millers Run Road (PA Route 50) and proceed to the traffic light at the T-instersection with Washington Pike in front of the Exxon station. Turn right onto Washington Pike and drive for for 2.1 miles to the intersection with Boyce Road. Turn right onto Boyce and proceed 1.4 miles to the traffic light at the intersection with Mayview Road.

If you want to enter the park through the wetlands, turn left on to Mayview road and drive for 1.1 miles to the railroad track crossing (indicated by “C” on the map). Park in the small triangle of land on the west side of Mayview Road bordered by the railroad tracks and Chartiers Creek. (There is room for only 2 or 3 cars.) Cross Mayview Road and enter the park through the gate to the wetlands.

To use the Boyce Road entrances to the park, continue on Boyce Road for another 0.5 mile to Ardolino's Pizza on the left. There is a paved turn off and parking area just past the pizza shop.

You can also use the garden plot parking area at the intersection with Morton Road. Proceed another 0.6 mile to the intersection with Morton Road on the left. Turn left and then another immediate left into the parking area (indicated by “A” on the map).

In any case, beginners are always welcome.  (Beginners do not need to bring supplies; and will receive advice on buying supplies they may want to purchase locally or online.)

Group, meet-up membership and instruction are free; donations (suggested $3-$5) to defray costs, however are welcomed.

Generally Sue Schneider, organizer, brings all supplies needed for projects/instruction.  (Additional supplies you may want to use at home are available for purchase.  If you have a specific request for official Zentangle products, kits, or tools, Sue will be happy to order them for you and deliver at the meet-up--you won't have to pay shipping costs!)

If you are a regular attender, simply bring your usual kit of supplies, and any other materials that may be specified for the particular session.

Fun, inspiration and good company are guaranteed!!

There is no requirement to register and no cost. All participants must be well. Please do bring your baby with you.

Pregnant mothers, currently breastfeeding mothers, mothers who are pumping and bottlefeeding, mothers who have breastfed in the past are all welcome to participate.

Meetings are led by a lactation consultant from Heritage Valley Sewickley. There is a scale available for weighing babies. Some meetings focus on a particular topic, but generally there is no specific topic. Specific topics can be addressed if requested by group participants.

Meetings of the Breastfeeding Moms Network are normally held on the 2nd and 4th Thursday evening of the month--except November and December when it is only the 2nd Thursday evening.

Storkbites is for all new mothers with a baby under a year old. Those meetings are on Tuesday mornings and moms can attend whether they are breast or formula feeding their babies.

results.description:
If you're into music, and even if you're not, here's a great opportunity to share any music you're interested in, have a cup of coffee or tea, and engage in conversation. We'll meet at Coffee Tree Roasters in Shadyside to chat, drink coffee, and listen to music. Bring your favorite music on your phone or thumb drive to share -- you can even bring an instrument to play if you'd like. And you can just come for the coffee and company – you absolutely aren't required to bring music (I will bring my laptop to look things up on YouTube as well).

Bring any music -- if you have music of your own creation, if you're passionate about a particular musician or band, or if you just like something and feel like sharing. It could be a recent find or something that influenced your childhood and got you though your teenage years. It could be something you love or it could even be something you hate -- just tell us why. Music is as much a story as anything -- it could be a story of you, or the story of the artist who created the music, or the story could be embedded in the song itself waiting for us to listen. Feel free to bring a story to share along with the music -- or not, if you prefer.

We're totally open to any kind of music so, please, bring anything you'd like to share be it classical, ethnic, heavy metal, or whatever -- even classical ethnic heavy metal (I bet it exists). We'll be meeting at Coffee Tree Roasters from 7pm (to probably 9pm though the room's booked until 10pm).

This event is also posted on meetin.org.
results.how_to_find_us: Inside Coffee Tree at 7pm, head to the glass-walled meeting room in the back.
results.name: Coffee Loves Music

results.description:
What: Swing Workshop with Gerald Ross

When: Thursday, April 14.  Time 7:00 to 9:00 pm

Where: WSCC, Trevanion room

ADMISSION: ONLY $35 in advance.  $40 day of event. Due to seating limitations, there will be a maximum number of RSVPs accepted; suggest you RSVP and pay early.

Children Welcome: Age 12 & Over Full Price; Under 12 - Half Price 

CONTACT/SIGN UP: http://www.meetup.com/Steel-City-Ukuleles/ Or Email: [masked]

PAY : Give check (payable to Steel City Ukuleles) or cash to Marlene or Jack; PayPal - Go to PayPal and make payment to [masked]. Contact Jack if you have questions. Cash ONLY on day of event.

Swing!  It’s a style, it’s a sound. Gerald Ross will teach us how to swing our favorite tunes. Here’s how he does it.


“Blue Moon” is a fun song to play on the ukulele. It uses the basic open-string chords we all know. BUT, using open-string chords does not achieve the sound and rhythm we associate with a bluesy, jazzy, swingy beat.  In this fun (Gerald is always fun), easy-to-understand workshop, we will learn a few closed position chords that will have you playing "Blue Moon" (and lots more) that correct swing sound. The material covered in this workshop is not exclusive to the blues/swing world, either. It can be used for all styles of music. 

No music theory needed. No music reading required. No knuckle-busting chord shapes to learn. Closed position chords use all four strings. Whether you are a confident and eager beginner or an advanced intermediate player, the take away will be play-changing. Workshops are a valuable tool in your uke education.

Gerald Ross is a musician specializing in American Roots Music – Swing, Early Jazz, Western Swing, Hawaiian, Ragtime and Blues. Playing the ukulele, guitar and lap steel guitar, he has performed throughout the USA and Europe and has recorded seven solo CDs. Ross currently tours as a solo act performing-teaching ukulele and steel guitar at festivals and music camps. He’s the founder and host of The Ashokan Music Camp. Gerald was SCU’s guest at our Anniversary Party last June.

Website:  http://geraldross.com

Gerald plays Slow Boat to China:  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qBp4JTm0N0A

Gerald plays Buck Dance:  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0PMoIoP8WuY
results.how_to_find_us: In the Trevanion Room, first floor
results.name: SWING Ukulele Workshop with Gerald Ross

results.description:
An advance welcome to you – our prospective guest…

Perhaps you’ve been thinking about going to a Toastmasters meeting for awhile.

Maybe you’re not quite certain what to expect, and so you’ve hesitated.

Given that fear of public speaking has ranked as the top phobia for quite some time, you’ve got plenty of company! At the same time, the most important skill, and it is indeed a “skill” -- not something that one is born with, or is “automatically” comfortable and effective for anyone -- is communication.

How we communicate influences most every aspect of our personal and professional lives. Wherever you happen to be in your communications process, the supportive environment of our club can make a positive difference. As renowned and respected motivational speaker Les Brown has maintained throughout his impressive career, “Practice makes improvement.”

You may notice that the emphasis is NOT upon perfection, but rather, upon effort and growth, over the course of time. We hope that you will consider Club 1104 – Penn Hills Toastmasters as a place where you can feel comfortable and encouraged as you embark upon your path to improved communication.

See you at the next meeting!

http://1104.toastmastersclubs.org/

results.description: The "Incito Veritas" founding fathers (which included females, of course, as no soul has a gender) originally called this group "Fight Club" and first intended to keep that name while maintaining secrecy. So much for that. But the spirit of Fight Club remains, the idea of trying to bring out the best in each other through the evolution of consciousness. As Brad Pitt said about the movie, "Fight Club is a metaphor for the need to push through the walls we put around ourselves and just go for it." And not fear the pain! In this meetup we discuss ways that concepts introduced during the Incito Veritas series can be applied to our daily lives. We will learn and grow as we process our experiences. Bottom line: Knowing and Not Doing is Not Knowing, or as it says in James 2:26, "For as the body without the spirit is dead, so faith without works is dead."

results.description:
A seminar presented by Amy Lohr, where the concept of "Sacred Pain" will be defined and explored.

A phrase coined by Amy to describe the commonality of the human experience: the culmination of pain and struggles that all of us experience on our life journey. Everyone has automatic impulses to brace against, resist, or tense to pain on a physical, emotional, mental, or spiritual level.  This "tensing to" and "resisting" pain helps us to initially survive; however, over time as you continue to avoid your pain, you struggle to heal and grow. 

It is counter-intuitive to embrace and accept your pain, and Amy proposes that learning how to safely experience your pain is what affords you the deepest growth. Your pain is worthy of being revered, honored, and held with care, compassion, and love. When you learn to honor your Sacred Pain in this way, you afford yourself the gifts of peace, healing, love, compassion, and wisdom. Ultimately, it is through your deepest, darkest, scariest experiences that you have the opportunity to experience the most significant growth. 

Amy will demonstrate creating a vessel for her Sacred Pain – a safe, sacred space where pain can be felt and experienced. Through sharing her story of adversity and resiliency, in passion and strength, you will observe the embodiment of Radical Acceptance with pain (the practice of mindfulness & compassion). A seminar that will empower and inspire you to practice the same skills with your Sacred Pain, and ultimately afford you the chance at deeper growth and healing.

~~~~~~


Stay tuned for additional seminars related to the concept of Sacred Pain, Mindfulness, Wellness, Spirituality & More! As we continue to explore new opportunities and methods to address the need for Mindfulness through practice, education, and embodiment.
results.name: Seminar: "Creating A Vessel For Sacred Pain"

Hello everyone!


Today's board games come in all different shapes, sizes, themes, components, and our group plays all kinds.. Here are some examples of the types of games we play...


Party games like:  Codenames, Spyfall, and Dixit.

Euro style games like:  Five Tribes, Orleans, Puerto Rico, Viticulture, and Lords of Waterdeep. 

Abstract games like:  Qwirkle, Blokus, and Hive

Card games like:  Dominion, Glory to Rome, Diamonds, and Munchkin

Those are just a few of the games that can be seen being played at our meetups every week.

Our members come in all shapes and sizes and span from young to older but all seem to have a great time when we get together!

Our organizers try to be very accommodating to new players and try to pick games appropriate to your skill level and that we think you would enjoy.  Our goal is to get you enthusiastic about the hobby.

If there is a game that you would like to try out just r.s.v.p. to one of our meetups and suggest it down in the chat.  Chances are that one of us has it in our collection and we can bring it out.

Look forward to introducing the hobby to many more players in 2016 and continued good times with our regulars.

Please r.s.v.p. early so I have an idea on how many people or coming and what games to bring along.  You can always cancel your r.s.v.p. if you have a change of plans.


See you soon!

Russ.

results.description:
April 15, 2016


Discover the science behind science fiction as we host a celebration of all things Sci‑Fi!
•This year marks the 50th anniversary of the creation of Star Trek. Join us in the Science Stage as we show the motion picture Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan.
•Snap a selfie with a Stormtrooper from Garrison Carida, a chapter of the 501st Legion or a member of the Rebel Legion.
•Mingle with members of the Steel City Ghostbusters and take a picture in front of the Pittsburgh Ecto-1, a replica of the ghost busting hearse, or the Steel City Time Machine.
•Discover the origins of Science Fiction starting with Mary Shelely's Frankenstein in our Works Theater show, Frankenscience. The show features our large Tesla coil, a one-million volt display of light and sound.
•Explore futuristic technology such as 3D printing – technology that would have been considered science fiction a few decades ago.
•Make your own ectoplasm slime to take home.
•For a few dollars more watch Special Effects on the biggest screen in Pittsburgh at Rangos Omnimax Theater. This throwback show from 1996 explores special effects techniques used in motion pictures, including traditional special effects up to modern computer generated effects. This film includes re-creation of several of the most breathtaking shots from the original Star Wars film in IMAX by Industrial Light & Magic and backstage looks at the making of Lucasfilm's epic Star Wars Trilogy Special Edition.

We will meet in the front lobby in front of the gift shop.
results.name: 21+ Night at the Science Center

Seating is limited, and reservations are encouraged.

results.description:
Conservatory Dance Company at the Byham Theater

Thursday, April 14 through Saturday, April 16, 2016
Byham Theater, 6th Street, Downtown

This performance showcases the diverse and impressive talents of Point Park University Conservatory Dance Company students, featuring an exciting array of dance legends and styles. Each has influenced the dance world’s past and inspires its future.

To many the highlight of the Conservatory Dance Company season, this production at the lovely Byham Theater in Pittsburgh’s Cultural District features magnetic pieces by some of the hippest names in contemporary American dance. Sonya Tayeh, known for her choreography for Madonna, the Martha Graham Dance Company, and Emmy-nominated pieces for So You Think You Can Dance, will choreograph a world premiere piece, alongside innovative works byballet luminary Matthew Powell, and the founders of MADBOOTS, the all-male contemporary dance company based in NYC. Award-winning choreographer Larry Keigwin will present Triptych, a minimalist abstract piece inspired by classic triptychs of photography. 


Past Conservatory Dance Company performances at the Byham have included pieces by such world renown choreographers as George Balanchine, Martha Graham, David Parsons, Dwight Rhoden, Alejandro Cerrudo, José Limón, Ben Stevenson and Raphael Xavier.

This year's showcase features some incredible works by the following choreographers: Larry Keigwin, MADBOOTS, Matthew Powell, and Sonya Tayeh.

Check out these great articles about this year's dance showcase during April 14-16 http://www.pghcitypaper.com/pittsburgh/a-conservatory-dance-company-program-offers-four-works-by-hot-contemporary-choreographers/Content?oid=1910504

http://www.post-gazette.com/ae/theater-dance/2016/04/13/Dance-preview-Point-Park-Conservatory-Dance-Company-to-feature-new-works-at-Byham-Theater/stories/201604130019

For more information about this performance, please visit http://www.pittsburghplayhouse.com/current-season/conservatory-dance-company/conservatory-dance-company-at-the-byham-theater#sthash.A5QFk7CK.dpuf


To check out other Point Park shows coming up (such as dance performances, plays, musicals) including those at the Pittsburgh Playhouse in Oakland as well as Point Park's George Rowland White Performance Studio downtown (near the corner of Wood and Blvd of the Allies), please visit http://www.pittsburghplayhouse.com/ and http://www.pittsburghplayhouse.com/tickets


Tickets Regular tickets are $20-$24 (or just $10 student/senior)


Because this show is not expected to sell out, you can save a little by just buying tickets at the door (Byham Theater Box Office).

This show is General Admission (open seating) so we could plan to meet beforehand so those people that would like to sit together as a group.

For example, the group could meet inside Backstage Bar (655 Penn Avenue, just two blocks from the Byham) for some free live jazz, quick food/drink, and pre-show gathering during 7-7:30 PM before walking over to the Byham together.

If you can't attend on Friday, April 15 please consider attending one of the other performances as shown below:

For more information about this show, please visit http://www.pittsburghplayhouse.com/current-season/conservatory-dance-company/conservatory-dance-company-at-the-byham-theater#sthash.A5QFk7CK.dpuf

results.description: All riders are welcome at our Saturday morning Beginner Ride. The average pace of this ride is 8-12 miles per hour. In other words, nice-n-easy. The beginner route includes residential riding and local bike paths, as well as 1 moderately busy, yet approachable intersection that we’ll tackle as a group. The Beginner Ride provides an opportunity to build basic riding skills including: ride with others in a group, ride safely and confidently when vehicles are present, bring the right gear on your ride, shift and brake comfortably and effectively. $125 ($50 deposit required by April 11). Address of class is provided to you after deposit is received.

RSVP & PAY DEPOSIT BY CLICKING HERE


In Reiki Level I students become acquainted with Reiki energy and are taught how to perform healing sessions on the self and others. Learning Reiki involves an energy activation process called an “attunement” which is performed by the Reiki Master with each student. Through this initiation ceremony students are opened to the flow of Reiki energy which provides an energetic shift, causing healing energies and intuitive insights to emerge. The initiation opens innate healing channels, enabling students to immediately tap into the flow of Reiki energy and perform healing sessions. In addition to learning the Reiki method of healing, students also experience an acceleration in their spiritual awareness and intuitive abilities as a direct result of the Reiki initiation. After learning Reiki, students report having increased energy, self-awareness, personal charisma, peace, and compassion.

Topics covered in Reiki Level I :
• What is Reiki and how the Reiki energy works
• The history of Reiki
• How to channel Reiki energy for self-healing and the healing of others
• Hand positions for self-healing and healing others
• Self-healing techniques for expanding personal awareness and accelerating well-being
• Hands-on practice both giving and receiving Reiki sessions
• Reiki and spiritual growth Class Duration: 7 hours

Reiki, The Healing Touch I and II manual by William Rand is included in the price which is a $20 value. A certificate is provided at the end of class showing completion of the class. $50 fee is required prior to the class to reserve seat. Please bring a bagged lunch.

Minimum of 2 students required.

results.description:
What:: GASP Games Day 
Where:: Springdale United Presbyterian Church 
When:: 10am to 11pm 
Cost:: $5 (first time attendees are free)

Games Days have been scheduled for the rest of 2016. See below for the schedule, it will be updated as needed.

2016 Dates

• January 30th - Springdale United Presbyterian Church 

• February 20th - Springdale United Presbyterian Church

• March 12th - Springdale United Presbyterian Church

• April 16th - Springdale United Presbyterian Church

• May 14th - Springdale United Presbyterian Church

• June 11th - Springdale United Presbyterian Church

• July 9th - Springdale United Presbyterian Church

• August 13th - Springdale United Presbyterian Church

• September 10th - Springdale United Presbyterian Church

• ** October 8th - Springdale United Presbyterian Church

• ** November 12th - Springdale United Presbyterian Church

• ** December 3rd or 10th - Springdale United Presbyterian Church

** Please note that one of the October or November dates will be dropped once we have GASPcon 2016 scheduled.  Also, one of the December dates will be dropped once the church knows when their annual Christmas party will take place.

The address for the church is located at the bottom of the page

Game Days run from 10am till 11pm, and are open to everyone. There is a small fee per person ($5) to attend Games Day, to cover the cost of the rental hall. This fee is waived for all first-time attendees. The fee will be collected when you arrive, and will grant access to all the games contributed by our members, for use that day. We will be holding off taking any new yearly payments, but those that did pay will be honored.

Speaking of games, there are always a multitude of board, card, role-playing, and miniature games being played on any given Game Day, but a few events are near constants.

• Our Multi-Player Magic League runs each Game Day, starting around 11am. It’s a league that runs Jan-Oct. There is a second league starting at 4:30PM with modified rules and decks, please read the forum post for more information.

• Several RPG campaigns are also run each Game Day, including our "One-Shot Saturdays", stand-alone adventures run by various GMs each month.

• There are several miniature games that regularly appear at each Game Day. These vary each month, but some examples are X-Wing, Bolt Action, Lord of the Rings, Firestorm Armada, Dystopian Wars, Axis and Allies: War at Sea & Angels 20, BattleTech, AT-43, Infinity, and others.

• Don’t forget our extensive board game contingent. You can always find players for a board game, whether you bring your own or try out one of the many titles our BGers own and bring each month to our Games Library.

We ask that everyone attending our Game Days brings something along as a snack and/or drink, for the community to share in. The facility has a full kitchen, so items that need refrigerated are OK. Most people bring some soda, chips, cookies, veggie tray, etc. This helps everyone have a good time without worrying about snacks or drinks.

See you at Games Day!


Location Information:: 
Springdale United Presbyterian Church 
859 Pittsburgh Street 
Springdale, PA 15144

results.description:
Detoxing is the body's way of getting rid of toxins. We all have toxins in our bodies and it's important to flush them out to remain healthy and balanced. In this class we will:
-Discuss what detox is and why it's important
-Understand different cleanses so you can find which one is best for you
-Learn how to detox in a safe, effective way
-Have the opportunity to create a customized detox plan for yourself.

Spring is a perfect time to boost your immune system and lose weight after winter.
Detox can bring mental clarity, focus, improved digestion, clear skin, more energy, and even emotional stability.
It's easy to eat packaged, fast food in America, because it's convenient and we're so busy!
When we eat these foods a lot, we get backed up and can potentially develop life threatening illnesses; that is why detox is so important.

We will discuss 5 different types of cleanses:
-Organic whole foods vegan diet
-Raw foods
-Fruit
-Juicing
-Water fasting


This is about listening to your body and developing a more loving relationship with yourself.
This class is 1hr. and the cost is $12.
After you sign up, I will email you the class notes and URL to the live event.
Here is the RSVP:
https://www.eventbrite.com/e/spring-detox-whatwhyhow-tickets-24189025025

I hope you can make it!!
Love Jenna ♥

results.description:
2016 Spring Foraging Workshop & Hike on Saturday, April 16th at North Park in Allegheny County, Pennsylvania

with Adam Haritan

http://learnyourland.com/event/spring-foraging-workshop-hike/

Spring is the perfect time to learn the skills involved in foraging for wild food. Roots, tubers, shoots, greens, buds, and flowers are among the various plant structures that are available for harvesting. Learn how to properly identify and harvest various wild species in Pennsylvania so that you can achieve greater levels of health, self-reliance, and nature connection.

The first part of the event will feature a presentation and discussion on springtime edible wild plants and mushrooms. During the second part of the event, we will explore the trails of North Park and discover, discuss, and learn about the edible plants in their habitats.

By attending the Spring Foraging Workshop & Hike on April 16th, you will learn:

*The importance of foraging for wild edible plants and mushrooms
*Sustainable harvesting practices
*Wild plant identification
*Tree identification
*Edible and medicinal uses of trees
*Wild plant nutrition
*Culinary applications
*Medicinal benefits

…and much more!

Interested in spending an afternoon with a great group of foragers? Here are the details:

When: Saturday, April 16th
Time: 1pm – 4:30pm
Where: North Park — Allegheny County, Pennsylvania
Investment: $45

While this event will mainly focus on edible plants and trees, we will also briefly discuss wild springtime mushrooms and other fungi.

This event will take place rain or shine, and it will entail light hiking. Space for this event is limited in order to maximize the learning environment, and registration with payment in advance is required. The exact meeting location will be provided upon registration.

To register, please contact me (Adam) at:
[masked]
results.name: Spring Foraging Workshop and Hike

In addition this club is also interested in learning about music theory, and potentially interested in forming a music band composed entirely of unusual musical instruments. We have a guy who made a guitar sound like a violin using an electric fan, a musical tesla coil, a soda can theremin, a DIY midi controlled pipe organ, and vacuum tube guitar amplifiers. You get the idea! This club is open to the public.

More information

www.hackpittsburgh.org

Come explore the Three Rivers Heritage Trail with our experts. We'll meet at the Millvale Riverfront Park Pavilion and pedal roughly 15 miles along the rivers, enjoying the sights of downtown. Please bring your bike and helmet as they are required. Show up a few minutes early so we can help you with a quick safety check on your bike. We highly recommend you bring a small day pack with extra clothes, snacks, water and any personal medications you may need. 


Thank you for your interest in our free "Bike Three Rivers Heritage Trail Outing." L.L.Bean has a new centralized reservation system. To guarantee your space, you must first confirm your reservation on our centralized reservation system, and if appropriate, fill out a participant agreement. Please visit <a href="http://www.llbean.com/pittsburgh">www.llbean.com/pittsburgh, find this event on the "Event Calendar", and register. We look forward to seeing you!

Your bicycle must be in good condition and ready to ride. Review the L.L.Bean Cycling Checklist to help you determine if your bicycle is in the appropriate riding condition.


Distance will be ~15 miles.

Dress in layers (avoid Cotton)

Snacks

Completed and signed L.L.Bean participant agreement ﻿Click Here﻿</a>

results.description:
RAHSAAN ROLAND KIRK: THE CASE OF THE THREE SIDED DREAM

Saturday, April16th - 2:30PM

Doors Open at 1:30 PM  Suggested Donation: $2


Q&A with SPECIAL GUEST: Rory Kirk (Son of Rahsaan Roland Kirk)

Best Documentary Winner of the 2015 Pan African Film Festival

Official Website: http://www.rahsaanfilm.com/

Official Trailer:

https://vimeo.com/84499769


SYNOPSIS (Courtesy of International Documentary Film Festival Amsterdam)


“The nose knows” is one of the pithy sayings of flamboyant jazz wunderkind Rahsaan Roland Kirk [masked]). The words roll across the screen in ornate, flaming letters – in fact, The Case of the Three Sided Dream regularly presents such text fragments graphically on the screen.

During long improvisations, Rahsaan–the name came to him in a dream – sometimes played three wind instruments at the same time, including with his nose. He was blinded by eye drops shortly after he was born, although he referred to himself as “a man that doesn’t see too well.” But he was blessed with a silver tongue; a fellow musician noted that, when onstage, Rahsaan liked to talk to the audience, more so than the other masters of jazz – a genre Rahsaan referred to as “black classical music.” 

The life story of this exceptional man is told by members of Rahsaan’s entourage, including colleagues, his widow and his son. Their stories are interspersed with short animations and archive footage, including from the Ed Sullivan Show and the Montreux Jazz Festival. In this way, we get a virtuoso portrait of a contrary figure: a fanatical collector of animal sounds, believer in an eccentric “religion of dreams” and champion of civil rights for African Americans – which resulted in the composition of a piece of music called "Blacknuss" that only uses the black piano keys.
results.name: Rahsaan Roland Kirk: The Case of the Three-Sided Dream Screens April 16th

results.description:
Vegan Pittsburgh (www.veganpittsburgh.org) is thrilled to be hosting an evening with Jasmin Singer of Our Hen House!

Join Vegan Pittsburgh at Mixtape Music Gallery for a reading and signing of Jasmin Singer's new memoir, ALWAYS TOO MUCH AND NEVER ENOUGH. Jasmin will give a brief talk and offer a reading from the book. You will have the opportunity to purchase a copy of the book and have it signed. The event is FREE! Vegan food and drinks will be available for purchase from Mixtape.

***

“Jasmin’s story is an inspiration to create your best self and your best life.” — Neal Barnard, M.D. New York Times bestselling author of Power Foods for the Brain

“[Singer] rigorously examines attitudes toward people battling obesity with compassion, insight and understanding.” — Joe Cross, filmmaker of Fat, Sick and Nearly Dead

About ALWAYS TOO MUCH AND NEVER ENOUGH:
Jasmin Singer’s struggle with weight defined her life. From the extra pounds and unrelenting bullies that left Jasmin Singer eating lunch alone in a bathroom stall at school, to the low self-esteem that left her both physically and emotionally vulnerable, Jasmin spent her younger years feeling completely lost.

Most people think there’s no such thing as a fat vegan. Most people don’t realize that deep-fried tofu tastes amazing and that Oreos are, in fact, vegan. So, even after Jasmin discovered her passion in advocating for the rights of animals, she defied any “skinny vegan” stereotypes by getting even heavier. More importantly, she realized that her compassion for others didn’t extend to her own body, and that her low self-esteem was affecting her health. She needed a change.

Told with humble humor and heartbreaking honesty, ALWAYS TOO MUCH AND NEVER ENOUGH: A Memoir (Berkley Trade Paperback Original; February 2, 2016; $16.00) is Jasmin’s story of how she went from a bullied kid who found solace in a box of cheese crackers to becoming an empowered activist and finding peace with herself, her body, and her sexuality.

By committing to monthly juice fasts and a diet of whole, unprocessed foods, Jasmin lost almost a hundred pounds, gained an understanding of her destructive relationship with food, and even learned some hard truths about how intensely our society values thinness.

In a relatable memoir about finding one’s true identity and what that really means, Jasmin Singer’s debut is a raw and powerful account of self-realization. Above all ALWAYS TOO MUCH AND NEVER ENOUGH is an inspiration to create one’s best self.


About Jasmin:
Jasmin Singer is the executive director of Our Hen House, a non-profit organization aiming to change the world for animals. She is the cohost of the Webby-recognized Our Hen House podcast, has written for numerous online publications including Huffington Post and MindBodyGreen, and has appeared on The Dr. Oz Show and HuffPo Live, and in the award-winning documentaries Vegucated and The Ghosts in Our Machine. Visit her online at http//www.jasminsinger.com, http://www.OurHenHouse.org/, on FB at Jasmin Singer, and on Twitter @jasmin_singer & Our Hen House


About Vegan Pittsburgh:
Vegan Pittsburgh aims to increase the accessibility and visibility of vegan dining options in the Greater Pittsburgh Area, to make the transition to veganism easy for everyone. To learn more, check us out at www.veganpittsburgh.org and https://www.facebook.com/veganpgh!
results.name: Book Signing & Reading with Jasmin Singer of Our Hen House

results.description:
This group is new, and is forming as the group grows. We will cover ongoing topics of metaphysics, and really anything that could be regarded as existing outside of objective reality, and seeks to investigate the nature of reality. Big words, but true. Simply put, the groups' questioning and desires to know the things that are hard to explain will define what each new topic is each month. So, as the group grows so do the topics.

This group is democratic where everyone is encouraged to join in the conversation, anyone can bring a gift to share--be it intuition, Reiki, dream work and lucid dreaming, numerology, astrology, Ascension, Enlightenment, meditation, visualization, channeling, archetypes, Angels, manifestation, Indigo Children and all of the other New Age children, Tarot, Shamanism, synchronicity, power animals and objects, multi-dimensional awareness, the 3rd, 4th, and 5th dimensions, the collective unconscious and collective conscious, spirit art, spirit guides, sacred space, empaths, medical intuition, past lives and I am sure much much more.

We decide as a group what we want to study and share. This is an open group, anyone can attend. The purpose is for spiritual, emotional and soul growth. This group is also a support group of sorts, as we grow more aware it can sometimes be a little scary. So, we are there for each other--we all have our own unique experiences to share and teach. At times we can bring in teaching guests to learn from.

The group is not only a forum and place where we can discuss and learn about metaphysics, but is also a place where each group member can share their experiences of this much shifting world where more and more people are feeling some sort of spiritual shift happening all around!

The first meeting will be a get together to decide what we want to study, and to get to know everyone. Every group meetup will begin with a meditation after introductions. Every group meeting will have a well wishing time at the end, as everyone share a message from their intuitive mind.

Most people wanted to meet on a weekend, so I chose the third Saturday of every month.

I was thinking about meeting at the Panera Bread Company on Center avenue in Oakland, they have a private meeting room I can set up for our group.
results.name: The Metaphysical Meetup Group

results.description:
Join us as we welcome Spring. Let your heart grow and bloom with Kirtan! One of the oldest music traditions of the world, kirtan call-and-response chanting comes to us from India.

This beautiful, blissful Sanskrit chanting & singing comes from the Bhakti Yoga tradition, the yoga of devotion and love. The energy of the chanting helps quiet the mind, uplift our spirit and connect us deeply to the center of our being. All are welcome to join in the singing or simply listen. Patti "Sangita" Spadaro is a professional guitarist/singer/songwriter & a yoga/meditation teacher. She's released several CDs & performed nationally.

Husband and wife team Ven and Veena Kelly have been leading kirtan for 17 years.
Together, this group of musical yogis radiates wonderfully good vibes!
Snacks and social time afterward. Bring a snack to share if you'd like. $10 cash/check, or online.
http://www.sriyantrayoga.com

The latest from one of the most original directors working today, Arnaud Desplechin. The NY Times called the film "transcendent". 

Recalling the best of Francois Truffaut, this evocative portrait of youth begins with a middle-aged anthropologist reflecting on his life. Through a series of flashbacks we see his early years as well as his life-changing student years, including a trip to the USSR where he meets a young Russian he considers a phantom twin. 

He remembers University life, and his shifting circle of friends. But most of all he remembers Esther, the beautiful, rude, love of his life. Premiered in the Directors’ Fortnight at Cannes. With subtitles.

Arnaud Desplechin | France | 2015 | 123 min

results.description:
Hi All,

We're meeting at 10:30AM at the tennis court of Cranberry community Park  and will play 2 hours or more.
If there are some people who want to play some tennis, please bring your racket and let's play together.

This is the event for all levels.
If you have any questions, please let me know.

Here is some guide I want to share with members. 


 ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
 TENNIS MEETUP RULES

1. Always RSVP before you come to the event. This helps in organizing and for reserving the courts. Note, without RSVP you may not have a spot.

2. If you RSVPed "Yes" and later decided to not come, please change the RSVP to "No" so the first member on the waiting list can get your spot.

3. Members are expected to arrive on time and stay for the duration. If you expect to be late more than 15 minutes, please send a text message to the posted organizer's phone number.

4. We will practice and always play a game - doubles or singles, depending on the number of members who come to the event.

5. The organizer will try to pair the teams based on skill levels but this may not always be possible and the pairing may be on a first-come-first-serve basis.

6. If a member is on the waiting list they can still come, however they may have to wait for courts to become available.
  ----------------------------------------------------------------------------

  Jason,
results.name: Sunday morning tennis for all levels - Cranberry

results.description:
Let's hang out! Take a walk... maybe a mile or two. Nothing too serious...If you think you're out of shape, join the club. We can do it together. Bring cameras, it's a beautiful area, bring some food, we can have a pick-nick. It's spring. We need some Vitamin-D. Any dogs who get along with others are welcome. I have a vizsla puppy.

Description of Mcconnells Mills below... 


McConnells Mill State Park, in Lawrence County, encompasses 2,546 acres of the spectacular Slippery Rock Creek Gorge. Created by the draining of glacial lakes thousands of years ago, the gorge has steeps sides and the valley floor is littered with huge boulders and is a national natural landmark. A gristmill built in the 1800s is open for tours. The park is open from sunrise to sunset, year-round.

results.description:
Looks like it's nice day Sunday, lets ride bikes around the city!

Looks like the weather on Sunday will be wonderful (75 degrees) perfect for a fun ride in the city! Mostly Trails but there will be some road riding.

Meet at: Hofbrau Haus Southside Works at 12:30pm. We'll leave at 12:40pm SHARP (I'm sticking to this...) Frank's contact phone number for TEXTING is[masked]

***Cross-Posted Event, more people than rsvp here will be here***

We'll then go on the trails past station square to Ft. Pitt Bridge. KETCHUP STOP number #1 AT FORT PITT BLOCKHOUSE!

Then to the North Shore going to Washington's Landing for a loop, then onto 31st Street Bridge to Klavons Ice Cream where we'll take a break. KETCHUP STOP number #2

Then we will ride back along the river past the convention center to the point. Trying to get a GROUP PICTURE at the FOUNTAIN. KETCHUP STOP number #3

We'll hit the Jail Trail and go to Hot Metal Bridge and then hang out at Hoffbrau House on the Patio for a Beverage and/or Food. KETCHUP STOP number #4 and FINAL DESTINATION.

Couple of Things:1. Make sure your bike is in good repair, pump up the tires, make sure brakes work.

2. This will have a bunch of Bikers, cause cross-posting, we're going to take it slow. We'll have KETCHUP POINTS where people can catch up (sorry Pittsburgh pun). We will overall try to keep people together but if you are impatient, or super fast just wait at the ketchup points.

3. If you don't have a bike you can RENT ONE! http://www.yelp.com/search?cflt=bikerentals&find_loc=Pittsburgh,+PA Or do the Healthy Bike Share program https://healthyridepgh.com/

4. This is just a short mellow ride. I'm assuming we'll have over 20+ people. We're Adults, you can do your own thing if you want. Just enjoy and be safe.

Cheers

Frank ;-)

Big Kahuna (ADMIN) of Pittsburgh Social Club, Free & Almost Free in Pittsburgh n 3 other meetups N'at!

Guest Speaker: James Porcelli

This presentation discusses patents, trademarks, and copyrights in terms understandable to the non-specialist. Included will be explanations on the processes for acquiring federal protection through patents, trademarks and copyrights, and how you know if you need such protection. 

James Porcelli has been a patent attorney for the past 25 years and has worked for the Webb Law Firm for the past 15 years. He worked as a mechanical engineer for 8 years prior to graduating from law school at the University of Pittsburgh.

This event is FREE and open to both members and non-members of TechShop Pittsburgh. It is not affiliated with any other group or companies. First-time visitors, please come early to check in at the Front Desk and receive a free tour of TechShop.

We usually play all day, break for dinner around 6:00, then it's back to gaming until everybody poops out. 

Incidentally, many of our regular players no longer bother to sign up (but I really wish they would!), so if it looks like only  one or two people are coming, there could actually be quite a few more.  Remember, I will always cancel a game Meetup if we aren't gaming that day, so you won't be sitting there all by yourself waiting for a friend.    And please, remember to change your rsvp to no if you can't make it that day!

results.description:
The Cost to attend? $0.00 BUT we do ask that you help us attract the most diverse (industry and background) set of entrepreneurs and create the most inclusive environment - this means inviting and bringing people, not just attending and participating.  


You can help us spread the word on Twitter or on Instagram or anywhere you can publish www.UnstuckPittsburgh.com using #UnstuckPgh 

Guidelines for the meet up:


1) Be on time, when you come in late (after 7:55AM) then you cause a disruption for everyone who got there on time.  Parents get a pass if they had to send someone off to school but otherwise please make best efforts to be early (help set up), get coffee, use the restroom, etc before we start.

2) No solicitation of services *cool if someone comes to you but consultants/lawyers/coaches beware, any sales pitches and you'll have to find a new Monday ritual

3) Make sure to state whether what you are saying is an opinion or fact (both very much welcome) so to not confuse anyone about where the point of view comes from

Location change: Repair The World - 6022 Broad St.

results.description:
Join us and attend one or all six Practice of Happiness/Positive Psychology master classes. Each month you will learn how to experience more joy, fulfillment, satisfaction, and happiness by applying the six components of positive psychology to your everyday life.

Laura Parkinson, who has a master's degree in counseling psychology and 30 years' corporate training experience, will present these master classes. Each class will include enthusiastic mini-lectures, lively discussions, recommended readings, and useful application exercises.

Fell free to attend any one of the six classes. If you attend all six classes, you will receive the Library's Certificate of Completion. Both teens and adults are welcome to attend. No registration is required.

All classes are FREE.

These are the dates and topics of each class:

1. Introduction to the practice of happiness/positive psychology, and in-depth focus on increasing your vitality. Monday, 2/15, 7-8:30 pm, room A.

2. Increasing your vitality applications review, and in-depth focus on expressing your true values and experiencing greater meaning. Monday, 3/14, 7-8:30 pm, room A.

3. Expressing your true values and experiencing greater meaning applications review, and in-depth focus on setting, achieving, and celebrating meaningful personal goals. Monday, 4/18, 7-8:30 pm, room A.
results.name: The Practice of Happiness/Positive Psychology Master Classes
