results.description:
Come and play ukulele with us at the Unitarian Universalist Church of the North Hills on the first and third Mondays of each month. All levels of play are welcome, and we are novice-friendly. Some people who come have never even held a ukulele, and if you contact Sandy ahead of time, she will bring an extra ukulele for you to try. Try it -- it's fun!

Music is usually selected from "The Daily Ukulele... 365 Songs for Better Living," by Liz and Jim Beloff. This book is readily available at music stores, book stores, and Amazon.com. Sometimes members bring other music to play (bring 15 copies to share). We usually play in a circle so bring a music stand if you have one  

Snacks and libations to share are welcome.

For more information, contact Sandy at [masked]

Directions to the Church: Take I279 North to Wexford exit. Turn right at the end of the exit. Right at the light onto Brandt School Road. Right onto West Ingomar Road to 2359. Note - watch for the large sign for the Church and then you will follow a narrow roadway back through the trees to the Church.

Depending on where you start, there may be a better route to the Church. Please check your GPS for different directions.

results.description:
Hi All,

We're meeting at 8:00 at the tennis court of Cranberry Community park and will play 2 hours or more.
If there are some people who want to play some tennis, please bring your racket and let's play together.

This is the event for all levels.
If you have any questions, please let me know.

Here is some guide I want to share with members. 


 ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
 TENNIS MEETUP RULES

1. Always RSVP before you come to the event. This helps in organizing and for reserving the courts. Note, without RSVP you may not have a spot.

2. If you RSVPed "Yes" and later decided to not come, please change the RSVP to "No" so the first member on the waiting list can get your spot.

3. Members are expected to arrive on time and stay for the duration. If you expect to be late more than 15 minutes, please send a text message to the posted organizer's phone number.

4. We will practice and always play a game - doubles or singles, depending on the number of members who come to the event.

5. The organizer will try to pair the teams based on skill levels but this may not always be possible and the pairing may be on a first-come-first-serve basis.

6. If you are a member on the waiting list, please don't come until there is cancellation and you moved in to the RSVP list of the event. 
  ----------------------------------------------------------------------------

  Jason,

results.description:
If you've never explored the Morton Valley Trail in Boyce-Mayview Park, you'll be in for a treat!  It's beautiful to walk through and has been rated one of the best walking trails in the city!   We will walk at a slow to moderate pace for about an hour.  Wear waterproof hiking shoes/ boots and dress accordingly to walking on trails that may be a bit muddy.  Bring a water bottle and snack if you'd like.  

Directions from US Rt. 19 (Washington Road)


Proceed south on US Rt. 19 (Washington Road) to Boyce Road which is 3.0 miles south of South Hills Village Shopping Center (at Ft. Couch Road). Turn right onto Boyce Road and proceed 0.5 miles to the intersection with Morton Road on the right. Turn right and then immediately left into the garden plot parking area (indicated by “A” on the map).

If the gate to the garden plots is closed or as an alternate, continue on Boyce Road another 0.6 miles to the paved turn-off just before Ardolino's Pizza on the right 

Another alternate entrance is on Mayview Road. Continue on Boyce Road to the intersection with Mayview Road (next traffic light) and turn right. Proceed 1.1 miles on Mayview Road to the railroad track crossing (indicated by “C” on the map). Park in the small triangle of land on the west side of Mayview Road bordered by the railroad tracks and Chartiers Creek. (There is room for only 2 or 3 cars.) Cross Mayview Road and enter the park through the gate to the wetlands.

Directions from Interstate 79

Take Bridgeville exit (No. 54) from I-79. At the end of the exit ramp, turn right onto Millers Run Road (PA Route 50) and proceed to the traffic light at the T-instersection with Washington Pike in front of the Exxon station. Turn right onto Washington Pike and drive for for 2.1 miles to the intersection with Boyce Road. Turn right onto Boyce and proceed 1.4 miles to the traffic light at the intersection with Mayview Road.

If you want to enter the park through the wetlands, turn left on to Mayview road and drive for 1.1 miles to the railroad track crossing (indicated by “C” on the map). Park in the small triangle of land on the west side of Mayview Road bordered by the railroad tracks and Chartiers Creek. (There is room for only 2 or 3 cars.) Cross Mayview Road and enter the park through the gate to the wetlands.

To use the Boyce Road entrances to the park, continue on Boyce Road for another 0.5 mile to Ardolino's Pizza on the left. There is a paved turn off and parking area just past the pizza shop.

You can also use the garden plot parking area at the intersection with Morton Road. Proceed another 0.6 mile to the intersection with Morton Road on the left. Turn left and then another immediate left into the parking area (indicated by “A” on the map).
results.how_to_find_us: We will meet at the paved turn off just before  Ardolino's Pizza on Boyce Road.  See detailed directions below

This is an interactive, online event that you can participate in from your computer. To join and get the access link, you must register at https://fifitwest.splashthat.com. 

----

With so much uncertainty, and so many questions to answer, validating your startup ideas can be overwhelming. Justin Wilcox, one of Founder Institute's most popular and highly rated mentors, has spent the last 18 months solving this problem. 

Combining the best of Customer Development, Design Thinking, Lean Startup, and Growth Hacking, Justin's "FOCUS Framework" (http://j.mp/_F0CUS) lays out an actionable path to validating your startup ideas, and achieving "Product-Market Fit." 

On this interactive online workshop, Justin will guide you through a step-by-step process to outline your ideas, test your riskiest assumptions, and run valid startup experiments to find your Product-Market Fit.

You'll leave the workshop with a clear, actionable, next step - and a practical strategy for finding your Product-Market Fit.

Don't miss this opportunity to participate in a unique, interactive online workshop! RSVP today at https://fifitwest.splashthat.com.

----

results.description:
Join us on Tuesdays for American Mah Jong! Folks begin arriving around 5PM, and play begins table by table as soon as we have three or four players plus a set.  (We usually have 3-5 tables.)  By 6:15 or so, most players have arrived. We rotate among the tables... at the end of each game, East walks around to see if another table is close to the end of their game, so that two players can swap places.   At the other end of the evening... play must end by 9PM when Panera closes.  Tables begin wrapping up play any time after 8:15 or so.


If you have never played, or if you have not played for a very long time, we highly recommend that you take a Mah Jong 101 beginner class before playing with us - beginner classes are offered every few months.  Mah jong is a wonderful game, but it's hard to learn by just watching others play!


Please order your 2015 card from the National Mah Jongg League, here: http://www.nationalmahjonggleague.org/ Amazon.com also carries the cards. Note that you want the NMJL card, and no other! (There are some colorful alternatives out there.. but we play NMJL card and rules.)

Experienced players -- please bring your cards and please bring a set if you have one.

Please do not bring any outside food or beverages into Panera! Instead, please plan to buy *something* from Panera, even if it's just a beverage or a cookie, to support their willingness to host us.
results.how_to_find_us: Hard to miss us, look for the Mah Jong sets!

results.description:
Let's venture downtown to Nola on the Square! Once there, we can enjoy a 5pm Happy Hour and a 6pm sit down dinner. 

Please make sure that you RSVP if you would like to join us for dinner (Please do NOT rsvp if ONLY attending the Happy Hour. Just leaving a comment would be fantastic! ). 

At this moment, we only have reservations available for 15 people.  But I will request more seats if our RSVPs fill up.  And of course, if you RSVP, but then find out that you cannot attend, please delete your RSVP, as space may be limited for dinner.  We look forward to seeing you!

It is PPDC's strict policy that any unannounced no-shows to a dinner will result in that member being BLOCKED from the group.  Also, to help me avoid the evil glares from restaurant managers when our initial number of attendees suddenly drops by half, if a member backs out (but gives advance notice) TWICE during their membership, they will also be BLOCKED from the group.  This is a very strict policy, and we strongly recommend that you do NOT reserve for a dinner until you are sure that you can attend.  This is very important, because I am being told that people are being discouraged from attending due to the events falsely being "fully booked."  Thanks!!!


A donation of a dollar per person would be appreciated, but not required, as the website is not free (please do not donate electronically...).  Yes, we accept quarters lollll....

Until then...!

Have a quick R presentation you want to do?  Want to teach yourself a new R topic?  Then sign up to give a lightning talk!

What are the rules?

You sign up to give a talk on any R topic you want in advance.  The day of the Meetup, you have ten minutes to give your entire talk.  There are no limits on content, presentation style or materials, or complexity, as long as your talk stays under 10 minutes and involves the R programming language in some way.

I want to give a talk!  How do I sign up?

Email [masked] and [masked] your topic and a quick summary of your talk.  If you have any time restrictions (e.g. you have to speak after 7PM), please include that as well.

New sponsors

We would like to thank Microsoft and Oracle for their financial support of this group.
results.name: April Meetup - Lightning Talks

results.description:
Please ask at the host stand for the book club. We are usually in the back room against the windows, but you never know...

for April, we're going #TBT to an author from our childhood! Judy Blume, known for classics like Fudge and Are You There God? It's Me, Margaret has also written a few adult novels.

In the Unlikely Event is about Miri Ammerman. From Amazon.com:

In 1987, Miri Ammerman returns to her hometown of Elizabeth, New Jersey, to attend a commemoration of the worst year of her life. Thirty-five years earlier, when Miri was fifteen, and in love for the first time, a succession of airplanes fell from the sky, leaving a community reeling. Against this backdrop of actual events that Blume experienced in the early 1950s, when airline travel was new and exciting and everyone dreamed of going somewhere, she paints a vivid portrait of a particular time and place—Nat King Cole singing “Unforgettable,” Elizabeth Taylor haircuts, young (and not-so-young) love, explosive friendships, A-bomb hysteria, rumors of Communist threat. And a young journalist who makes his name reporting tragedy. Through it all, one generation reminds another that life goes on.
In the Unlikely Event is vintage Judy Blume, with all the hallmarks of Judy Blume’s unparalleled storytelling, and full of memorable characters who cope with loss, remember the good times and, finally, wonder at the joy that keeps them going.
results.why: We love to read, drink wine and talk about books!

results.description:
“I am Uhtred, son of Uhtred, and this is the tale of a blood feud. It is a tale of how I will take from my enemy what the law says is mine. And it is the tale of a woman and of her father, a king. He was my king and all that I have I owe to him. The food that I eat, the hall where I live, and the swords of my men, all came from Alfred, my king, who hated me.”

“Like Game of Thrones, but real” (The Observer, London)

The Last Kingdom tells the story of England in the 9th and 10th centuries, when Alfred the Great and his descendants battled the Vikings who invaded and occupied much of the country. The story is told by Uhtred, child of an English nobleman, captured by the Danes and raised as one of them, who returns to England as a Viking warrior with hopes of regaining his family’s lost lands. The story of Uhtred’s struggle with his place as both a Viking and an Englishman is rich with battles, warriors, royalty, religion and court intrigue.

This is the first book of what was apparently meant to be a trilogy but has grown into at least 8 books. We’ll only read the first one! It’s recently been made into a series for BBC television.
results.name: The Last Kingdom by Bernard Cornwell

results.description:
Join us for a 2-hour session of indoor volleyball open gym! You'll get a ton of playing time in a well-organized event. Our host will check players in, divide players into teams, and make sure that everything runs smoothly. All you have to do is show up ready to play!

Pricing:

• $7 - RSVP online and pay in advance because you know you are attending. (online rsvp closes at 4:30 pm!)

• $8.50 - RSVP and pay 50 cents via PayPal and $8 cash at the event if you are pretty sure you are attending (note the 50 cents is non-refundable)

• $10 - Show up and play - be sure to check online to make sure there is room!

What to Wear: We are playing indoors on a rubberized all-sport surface. Most players wear volleyball-specific shoes, but gym shoes are also allowed. Please bring your shoes and change into them at the facility. This will help keep the floor clean of dirt and water.

What to Expect: Show up early! The games will begin at the time posted for this event. Players can start checking in with the event host as early as 15 minutes before the scheduled start time. If a court is available, you may begin warming up before the event begins. We limit play to 42 players per evening, which is 3 teams of 7 players per court. If we have 3 teams on a court, winners stay once and then shuffle out so everyone gets to play. If less people are in attendance, we divide based on who is there and mix things up half way through the session.

Level of Play: This event is open to all levels of play. We do our best to create even teams so that games are well-matched. Our ideal scenario is having one court of higher skilled players and one court of more recreational players. There are no referees, so players need to play with sportsmanship and make their own calls. We aim to make everyone feel welcome at these events.

Facility Information: Monroeville Sports Center is located at 855 Macbeth Drive in Monroeville. Parking should be ample in the free lot.

Minimum number of players and playing formats. This event needs a minimum of 12 people (not including the host) signed up before the start of the event in order to run. An email notification will be sent if we cancel. Refunds or credits will be issued if we cancel the event. Sign up early to encourage more people to sign up!!

Do Your Part! Help us keep an accurate guest count! If you RSVP, we're counting on you to be there. If you change your mind about playing or your guest count changes, please update your RSVP. No-Shows will be marked on your account. If space is tight, we hold RSVP spots 10 minutes into advertised start and then open spots to walk-ups.

Requirements to play: This is an adult volleyball group. You must be 19 older. Males and females of all skill levels are welcome to play. There is no required gender ratio. Players are expected to conduct themselves with good sportsmanship.

What's included in the price? Your payment helps to cover the rental costs, the hourly pay for your event host, and ensures a well-organized event.

Questions? Post your question in the comments section of this meetup and the event host or one of our organizers will reply. You can also message the organizers directly through meetup. Or, give us a call M-F 8:00am-12:30pm:[masked]-7130.

results.description:
We are pleased to invite you to a timely Health 2.0 Pittsburgh event,
“HIT Solutions for Coordinating Referrals and Services across Organizations.”


Meeting Date and Time

Wednesday, April 20, 2016

5:00 p.m. to 8:00 p.m.

Location

QI2T Center

Centre City Tower, Suite 2600

650 Smithfield Street

Pittsburgh, PA 15222

This Health 2.0 Pittsburgh event is timely as CMS encourages primary care, social service, and behavioral health organizations to coordinate referrals and services across providers, and when our community is preparing for the implementation of managed long-term services and supports (Community HealthChoices). At the same time, many community health workers, outreach workers, navigators, and care managers in patient-centered medical homes and accountable care organizations seek to make referrals and provide navigation support seamlessly beyond the walls of medical buildings. 

As a result, we are pleased to announce that this Health 2.0 event will feature nationally-recognized technology solutions to help coordinate services across settings of care: Healthify, GSIHealthCoordinator, and BluePrintHIT.

Following a networking session with drinks and a light dinner at the QI2T Center, Melonie Behan, Lynne Nelson, and Bob Bontempo from GSI Health, Mike Squires from BluePrint Healthcare IT, and Eric Conner from Healthify will demo their HIT systems.

You will see how:


·  GSIHealthCoordinator integrates medical, social, and behavioral information across the community, navigates care across different entities, delivers holistic care via an individualized care plan, and supports population health through risk stratification and predictive analytics;

·  BluePrintHIT Care Navigator™ coordinates care and tasks across the entire care team—both within and outside the organization; and

·  Healthify recommends services based on assessments, makes referrals from healthcare providers to community-based social service agencies, verifies completed referrals, and tracks community needs.

After the demos, Bruce Block, MD, the Pittsburgh Regional Health Initiative’s Chief Learning and Informatics Officer, will summarize the major game changers and pose thought-provoking questions to engage us in a lively exchange of ideas with Melonie, Mike, and Eric. We will close with another opportunity to network. 

We hope you will be able to attend this event, and network with a diverse mix of technology developers, entrepreneurs, funders, healthcare providers, administrators, public health leaders, students, and theme-specific stakeholders. The intent is to share ideas among all participants about the frontier of technology in the service of health integration. 

Please RSVP by Tuesday, April 12th by contacting Ben Johnston at [masked] or[masked]-6714. Space is limited, and we will be accepting RSVPs on a first come, first serve basis. If your plans change after RSVP’ing, please let us know, so we may accommodate others.


Sincerely,

Robert Ferguson

Director of Government Grants and Policy

About Health 2.0 Pittsburgh

Health 2.0 Pittsburgh connects disruptive technology solutions to contemporary, important community health issues through local forums organized by the Jewish Healthcare Foundation. During the events, topic experts and a mix of students, funders, technology developers, and entrepreneurs network, frame and explore the issue, and showcase technology solutions that match the issue.

About the Health Innovators


GSI Health is an award-winning provider of care management IT solutions supporting value-based programs. GSI Health’s flagship offering, GSIHealthCoordinator, is a cloud-based software-as-a-service (SaaS) platform that combines care coordination and community-based care delivery with a reporting and analytic engine for extracting insights and continually synthesizing improvements in care. GSI Health provides a broad array of capabilities. They are an early leader in Delivery System Reform Incentive Payment (DSRIP) solutions for performing provider systems, including implementations in two of the largest performing provider systems in the state of New York. GSI Health is extending its leadership into the emerging children’s health home market. http://www.gsihealth.com/company-overview


Care Navigator™ is a web- and mobile-based Patient Relationship Management platform. It provides real-time, team-based care navigation, coordination, and communication from within and beyond the walls of healthcare organizations. It is built on a workflow-driven foundation connected to secure, encrypted mobile apps for all three major operating systems through a HIPAA-compliant cloud-based architecture. Its mobile platform can also be "untethered" and connected to existing clinical care management systems through web-services. http://www.blueprinthit.com/care-navigator

Healthify is a software tool for care managers, community health workers, and social workers to coordinate referrals with community-based organizations. It includes a Community Resource Platform that allows users to search, filter, and refer to community organizations, social services, and government benefits. The Healthify Referral Tracking Platform allows care teams to refer patients in need of social services to community organizations, and users can verify completed referrals by communicating directly with community services. Healthify's Assessment Platform can automatically recommend services to address patient needs identified in assessment tools, and the Healthify Analytics Platform allows users to see trends in community needs. https://www.healthify.us/healthify-application
results.name: HIT Solutions for Coordinating Services across Organizations - RSVP by 4/12

results.description:
A recent survey found that 94% of companies plan to adopt Agile in the next year. Astoundingly over 50% of all Agile transformations either fall short or fail outright. Where did they go wrong? Few organizations prepare themselves for the cultural and mindset shift that comes with Agile. Instead, they focus on the tactics. Worse yet, they utilize waterfall project management or antiquated OCM (organizational change management) techniques to transform. It’s the equivalent of a vegan chef running a steakhouse.

This talk will cover the motivations for chance, success factors and avoiding common pitfalls.

This is an encore presentation of Nivia Henry's Codemash 2016 presentation.
results.name: Ready, Set, Change! A look at Agile Adoptions & Transformations

Please note: We are going to meet at 6:50 pm. Meetup has time slots in 15 minutes increments so I had to select 6:45. We are doing this so that a few of our riders that work a later work day can join us. And now that it's light out, were not meeting in the dark.

To the group, I am repeating Alex's Hump Day ride. With the days getting longer let's try to resume the weekly North Shore rides. Herr's Island parking lot, 6:50 pm. With the Pirate game, I am recommending that take the 31t bridge to the Strip District Trail to the Convention Center. We will shoot down 27th street, then the 3 Rivers Heritage Trail to the Point, cross over to the Fort Duquesne Bridge to the North Shore, ride to the Penitentiary, then back via the North Shore Trail, by that point the game will be in progress....

Everyone seems to be in favor of Pho Van in the strip for our post-ride repast! 

Link to 12 mile loop

All trail. Beginner level, we will ride as slow as needed. Fast riders are welcome to ride ahead on their own. Estimated time - an hour and a half.

We will start at 6:30. The sun sets at 7:58 and we should be back at the island before 8. We are strongly recommending a tail and headlight, although the sun sets around 8: 00. They are calling for 65* Any questions - call Diana at (412)[masked]

results.description:
In March, we found there is a separate room at this Giant Eagle with comfy chairs.  Go through the main seating by the beer sales.  At the end of those tables, there is a door into the separate room.  As long as people aren't in there, we'll meet in there.

Our April book choice is French Coast by Anita Hughes

Serena has the job she's always dreamed of and Chase, the man her heart never dared to. As a new editor at Vogue, she bags the biggest interview of the year with Yvette Renault, the infamous former editor of French Vogue, in The Carlton-InterContinental Hotel during the Cannes Film Festival. She eagerly jets off to France while Chase stays home, working with her father, a former senator, on his upcoming mayoral campaign.

Everything feels unbelievably perfect...until it doesn't. The hotel loses her reservation hours before her big interview. Serena fears that she'll have to go home without her story, but then she meets Zoe, a quirky young woman staying in the suite below Yvette's who invites Serena to stay with her. Serena is grateful for her mysterious roommate's generosity, but it seems that there's more to her story than meets the eye. To make matters worse, soon after arriving in Cannes, Serena learns a shocking secret about her parents' marriage, and it isn't long before she begins to question her own relationship. With her deadline looming and pressure mounting, Serena will have to use her investigative journalism skills, new friendships, and a little luck to get her life and love back on track. 

Fast paced and impeccably written, French Coast will draw readers in to the intoxicating world of the Cote D'Azur. Hughes' beautiful prose and sense imagery bring the food, fashion, and feel of the ocean to life in this audacious new novel.

D&D Encounters is a weekly Wednesday play program, geared for casual players audience with short sessions each week. It serves as a great introduction to our main storyline events, and uses material right from published adventure product.

Each session only takes 1-2 hours to play, so it’s easy to fit your game in after school or work. And each week there’s a new and exciting challenge. Jump in anytime!

results.description:
Radio behaves one way in the lab but in the field you need to consider a few more factors. We'll discuss Free Space Path Loss, bending radio around the curvature of the Earth, and wave polarity. Then we'll discuss how we can use technology to solve all those bad radio behaviors that reduce throughput in our wireless signals.

The goal of this series of talks will be to encourage participation in the installation crew that will build Braddock's WiFi network this summer. See The Full Schedule to get more details. Registration is not necessary for this event.

Food will be free or subsidized through BEDCO and Meta Mesh from a pizza location or a hoagie place. We'll see. We're still working out the details.
results.name: WiFi Basics 3: Radio on Planet Earth and the Dark Arts of WiFi

results.description:
Why are schools, corporations, even the military promoting meditation for their students, employees, and soldiers? Because magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) studies are revealing its very real benefits for improved responses to the stresses of daily life: lower blood pressure, improved mental functioning, deeper sleep, and reduced physical pain, just to name a few. Does this sound like a better way to live? 


The Bright Path offers The Ishayas’ Ascension, a meditation grounded in simple, mechanical techniques that employ the uplifting attitudes of Praise, Gratitude, Love and Compassion. Practiced regularly, these techniques can replace a lifetime of judgment, self-defeating habits, and negativity with a consistently more positive, expansive experience of life. Are you ready to re-set your relationship with your mind? Are you ready to live a life you will truly love? Come learn how simple it can be – and bring your friends! 


About the Speaker: A retired IUP professor, Dharani Ishaya (Dr. Tina Perdue) taught college-level courses in writing and public speaking for 37 years. After she learned the Ishayas' Ascension meditation in 2005, the benefits she experienced in her own life led her to Spain, where she recently completed six months of training to teach this powerful and effective meditation. She continues to live in Indiana PA, where she supports members of a thriving meditation community as they transform their lives. 


To learn more about Bright Path visit www.thebrightpath.com/about
results.name: Living a life you'll love! Free Meditation Information Session

results.description:
Hi All,

We're meeting at 7:30 PM at the tennis court of Cranberry Community park and will play 2 hours or more.
If there are some people who want to play some tennis, please bring your racket and let's play together.

This is the event for all levels.
If you have any questions, please let me know.

Here is some guide I want to share with members. 


 ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
 TENNIS MEETUP RULES

1. Always RSVP before you come to the event. This helps in organizing and for reserving the courts. Note, without RSVP you may not have a spot.

2. If you RSVPed "Yes" and later decided to not come, please change the RSVP to "No" so the first member on the waiting list can get your spot.

3. Members are expected to arrive on time and stay for the duration. If you expect to be late more than 15 minutes, please send a text message to the posted organizer's phone number.

4. We will practice and always play a game - doubles or singles, depending on the number of members who come to the event.

5. The organizer will try to pair the teams based on skill levels but this may not always be possible and the pairing may be on a first-come-first-serve basis.

6. If you are a member on the waiting list, please don't come until there is cancellation and you moved in to the RSVP list of the event. 
  ----------------------------------------------------------------------------

  Jason,
results.name: Wednesday evening tennis for all levels - Cranberry

results.description:
If you've never explored the Morton Valley Trail in Boyce-Mayview Park, you'll be in for a treat!  It's beautiful to walk through and has been rated one of the best walking trails in the city!   We will walk at a slow to moderate pace for about an hour.  Wear waterproof hiking shoes/ boots and dress accordingly to walking on trails that may be a bit muddy.  Bring a water bottle and snack if you'd like.  

Directions from US Rt. 19 (Washington Road)


Proceed south on US Rt. 19 (Washington Road) to Boyce Road which is 3.0 miles south of South Hills Village Shopping Center (at Ft. Couch Road). Turn right onto Boyce Road and proceed 0.5 miles to the intersection with Morton Road on the right. Turn right and then immediately left into the garden plot parking area (indicated by “A” on the map).

If the gate to the garden plots is closed or as an alternate, continue on Boyce Road another 0.6 miles to the paved turn-off just before Ardolino's Pizza on the right 

Another alternate entrance is on Mayview Road. Continue on Boyce Road to the intersection with Mayview Road (next traffic light) and turn right. Proceed 1.1 miles on Mayview Road to the railroad track crossing (indicated by “C” on the map). Park in the small triangle of land on the west side of Mayview Road bordered by the railroad tracks and Chartiers Creek. (There is room for only 2 or 3 cars.) Cross Mayview Road and enter the park through the gate to the wetlands.

Directions from Interstate 79

Take Bridgeville exit (No. 54) from I-79. At the end of the exit ramp, turn right onto Millers Run Road (PA Route 50) and proceed to the traffic light at the T-instersection with Washington Pike in front of the Exxon station. Turn right onto Washington Pike and drive for for 2.1 miles to the intersection with Boyce Road. Turn right onto Boyce and proceed 1.4 miles to the traffic light at the intersection with Mayview Road.

If you want to enter the park through the wetlands, turn left on to Mayview road and drive for 1.1 miles to the railroad track crossing (indicated by “C” on the map). Park in the small triangle of land on the west side of Mayview Road bordered by the railroad tracks and Chartiers Creek. (There is room for only 2 or 3 cars.) Cross Mayview Road and enter the park through the gate to the wetlands.

To use the Boyce Road entrances to the park, continue on Boyce Road for another 0.5 mile to Ardolino's Pizza on the left. There is a paved turn off and parking area just past the pizza shop.

You can also use the garden plot parking area at the intersection with Morton Road. Proceed another 0.6 mile to the intersection with Morton Road on the left. Turn left and then another immediate left into the parking area (indicated by “A” on the map).

results.description:
Get Heard! Get Noticed! Get Leads! (TM)


This event is hosted by Tammy Adkins with RAIN International and co hosted by Kobbie Alamo, Independent Consultant for Arbonne.

This is an informal networking event, open to any business woman who would like to increase her business contacts or clients in the Irwin area.

Things to bring:

- 10-20 business cards or marketing material

- cash for your lunch check

- $5 meeting fee (non members only)

AGENDA

1:00 pm - attendees arrive, reviews menu, gives the server their drink order, and open networking: everyone stands up to introduce oneself to others and pass their business card

1:15 pm - server takes lunch order and the sign in sheet is passed around

1:30 pm - 60 sec. commercials begin

2:00 pm - each person gives a testimony or referral for someone attending the lunch

2:30 pm - Premier member does a 5 min. company presentation

2:35 pm - WSBA announcements from Debi/Susan

2:45 pm - lunch has ended. Open networking is welcomed.

Be prepared to do a 60 second commercial about yourself. Please RSVP if you plan to attend this lunch. If your schedule becomes free the day of the lunch, then you may attend without an RSVP. This lunch is subject to cancellation when the lunch has 3 or less RSVPs. Lunch cancellation policy.

If you are not a WSBA member and would like to attend as a guest, please contact Alike Royal, WSBA ADMIN. ASSISTANT,  at [masked]

If you have an interest in becoming a General member ($50/year) or Premier member ($100/year) of WSBA, please contact Jane Nespoli - [masked]

Any non member will be subject for removal from this site, when they RSVP that they are attend, and they are a no show.

This is a discussion group EN FRANCAIS for those (intermediate and higher) wishing to perfect their conversational French.

I will bring materials for learning/teaching.  This will include 1 song, but there will also be a chapter from intermediate to advanced grammar and conversation textbooks, as well as articles.

I will also focus on practicing authentic French phrases and pronunciation.

I say this, because many Americans have reached a plateau in their language learning - and this is totally normal.  BUT in order to progress to the next level, some heavy lifting is in order. 

Homework (reading, writing, listening) will be assigned, also.

Exciting details to be announced shortly. What is most important to know is that you'll enjoy the company of women who affirm the Sacred Feminine, the life-giving power of all women, be they maiden, mother or crone.


Maidens are women of any age who are independent and free of major responsibilities, women who are free to sample all the offerings of life.

Mothers are women who are devoted to developing special projects. The project may be the raising of children, the growth of a business or career, or the blossoming of her art.

Crones are defined as women who no longer menstruate or who have attained the age of 56 or who have a daughter who is in a permanent (hopefully) relationship with her sweetheart. When menstruation stops, the wise and powerful blood stays within and blesses the crone with wisdom. Or so we hope. (smile)

results.description: The "Incito Veritas" founding fathers (which included females, of course, as no soul has a gender) originally called this group "Fight Club" and first intended to keep that name while maintaining secrecy. So much for that. But the spirit of Fight Club remains, the idea of trying to bring out the best in each other through the evolution of consciousness. As Brad Pitt said about the movie, "Fight Club is a metaphor for the need to push through the walls we put around ourselves and just go for it." And not fear the pain! In this meetup we discuss ways that concepts introduced during the Incito Veritas series can be applied to our daily lives. We will learn and grow as we process our experiences. Bottom line: Knowing and Not Doing is Not Knowing, or as it says in James 2:26, "For as the body without the spirit is dead, so faith without works is dead."
results.name: Fight Club: Ready ... Set ... Action!

group.name: Quantum CB/New Eyes: Exploring Your Infinite Possibilities

results.description:
Attempting to organize the largest game of Red Rover!
Each contestant will be assigned a number as to the order they arrive.
Odd on one side, even on the other.

Each side will call off the numbers in order via megaphone until the last person is standing.


The purpose of the game is simply to make people smile, get them out of the house for the day, and to let anyone be apart of something that is a world record.


We intend to make no money, and simply to let the event grow from a Facebook event.  https://www.facebook.com/events/420114068171104/


The idea was brought into conception sitting at "The Point" in Point State Park in Pittsburgh, Pa, which is the perfect forum for it because it is a large, long public park.
We chose earth day 2016 to represent human unity. The time we selected is 4pm.
results.how_to_find_us: Use the FB Link for more info!

results.description:
*******************VENUE CHANGE******************** 



Hello Western PA Gamers!

Since Kings changed their hours our die hard gamers have been looking for a venue to that stayed open past 11:00 PM on Friday nights.  One of our member Dom from the MMOXIE Geek and Gamer Social Club found has been holding some meetups at the new Giant Eagle Market District in Settler's Ridge and we are going to team up with them on this meetup for a combined event.  

The venue has hot food, snacks, hard and soft drinks and is open 24 hours!  It is first come first serve on the seating but I will plan on being there at 5:00 and try to reserve a few large tables up on the second floor.  From what I have been told they have four large round tables that seat 6 and several booths that will accommodate four.  It gets a little crowded at dinner time but thins out after 7:00 or so.  This should take the pressure off people who want to get their gaming on to get there by 5:00 like at Kings since we can go again to the wee hours of the morning!  :-)

It is also nice to have a spot where our Airport area players can get to quickly as well as the Northern and City players. This location is probably only 15-20 minutes from the Fort Pitt tunnel.  

I still have the Kings reserved for the 15th and 29th of April but if this location works out we could look at alternating the venue from week to week.

Today's board games come in all different shapes, sizes, themes, components, and our group plays all kinds.. Here are some examples of the types of games we play...


Party games like:  Codenames, Spyfall, and Dixit.

Euro style games like:  Five Tribes, Orleans, Puerto Rico, Viticulture, and Lords of Waterdeep. 

Abstract games like:  Qwirkle, Blokus, and Hive

Card games like:  Dominion, Glory to Rome, Diamonds, and Munchkin

Those are just a few of the games that can be seen being played at our meetups every week.

Our members come in all shapes and sizes and span from young to older but all seem to have a great time when we get together!

Our organizers try to be very accommodating to new players and try to pick games appropriate to your skill level and that we think you would enjoy.  Our goal is to get you enthusiastic about the hobby.

If there is a game that you would like to try out just r.s.v.p. to one of our meetups and suggest it down in the chat.  Chances are that one of us has it in our collection and we can bring it out.

Look forward to introducing the hobby to many more players in 2016 and continued good times with our regulars.

Please r.s.v.p. early so I have an idea on how many people or coming and what games to bring along.  You can always cancel your r.s.v.p. if you have a change of plans.


See you soon!

Russ.

results.description:
Allegheny Observatory hosts public tours on the third Friday of each month, except January. April should be warm enough to integrate this with a bike ride in Riverview Park.

6:30 - meet at the bottom parking lot of Riverview Park and ride some loops. The loop in the park is two miles long, and we can do two to four, riding at individual pace (it's a very low traffic road with bike lanes). We can split into several groups of different speed or even ride individually.


7:30 - regroup by the observatory and proceed to the tour (bring a bike lock)


After the tour (around 10 pm) we will bike back to the bottom of the hill. It will be dark by then so bring lights.

The tours are free but registration is required.
http://www.pitt.edu/~aobsvtry/tours.html
Please RSVP now if you are interested. The details are provisional and may change. I will update this page accordingly. I will also contact everyone who RSVP'd yes a few weeks in advance, to confirm attendance before I make a reservation.
results.name: Allegheny Observatory Public Tour

results.description:
The Cake Therapist     by Judith Fertig

3.30  ·   Rating Details  ·  797 Ratings  ·  171 Reviews

A fiction debut that will leave you wanting seconds, from an award-winning cookbook author.


Claire “Neely” O’Neil is a pastry chef of extraordinary talent. Every great chef can taste shimmering, elusive flavors that most of us miss, but Neely can “taste” feelings—cinnamon makes you remember; plum is pleased with itself; orange is a wake-up call. When flavor and feeling give Neely a glimpse of someone’s inner self, she can customize her creations to help that person celebrate love, overcome fear, even mourn a devastating loss.

Maybe that’s why she feels the need to go home to Millcreek Valley at a time when her life seems about to fall apart. The bakery she opens in her hometown is perfect, intimate, just what she’s always dreamed of—and yet, as she meets her new customers, Neely has a sense of secrets, some dark, some perhaps with tempting possibilities. A recurring flavor of alarming intensity signals to her perfect palate a long-ago story that must be told.

Neely has always been able to help everyone else. Getting to the end of this story may be just what she needs to help herself.
results.how_to_find_us: Ask for the Book Club
results.name: Moon/Sewickley Meetup: The Cake Therapist by Judith Fertig

Our initial event, get in on the ground floor!  S Hills Village Olive Garden is a great middle-price-range venue; clean, beautiful setting, wonderful service, modest prices.  All Italian dishes and pasta, and the shrimp scampi, are exceptional, unlimited salad, and the hot rolls are as good as it gets.  

Friday evenings are crowded, so we have to limit this one to the first 20 RSVPs.  If you RSVP 'YES', please show up.  numbers 21 through 27 (I'll notify you!) should come, there will still probably be a few no-shows, and worst-case scenario you might have to wait an extra 5 or 10 minutes;  the manager, Charley, will still try to seat you with the group.


I also recommend showing up just a little early, so we can start filling up seating as it becomes available a little before 7.  I'll be there early; I'll be wearing dark blue with dark blue sunglasses, that should be easy to spot!  You're going to have a real good time, and a real good dinner.

results.description:
Register Here


Join us for an exciting hike during the full moon. Please wear appropriate hiking clothing, waterproof footwear (if possible) and dress for the weather (layers; no cotton). Please bring a small day pack with extra clothes, snacks, water and any personal medications you may need. Ages 8 and up are welcome. Hope to see you on the trail!


Thank you for your interest in our free "Full Moon Hike Outing." L.L.Bean has a centralized reservation system. To guarantee your space, you must first confirm your reservation on our centralized reservation system, and if appropriate, fill out a participant agreement. Please visit www.llbean.com/pittsburgh, find this event on the "Event Calendar", and register. We look forward to seeing you!

Activity Level:
Physical Ability/Cardiovascular Demand: Easy
Level of Experience: Intro

Hike distance will be about 4 miles

What to bring:
Dress in Layers (avoid Cotton)
Sturdy Hiking Boots
Two Light Sources: Headlamp, Flashlight, Extra Flashlight, etc.
Water to stay hydrated 
Snacks 
Completed and signed L.L.Bean participant agreement Click Here


Additional: Lip Balm, Camera, Change of Shoes, Dry Bag, Walking Stick or Trekking Poles, Personal Medicines, Eye Protection

Minimum Age 8: This outing is open to ages 8 and above. Children 8 to 14 years of age need to be accompanied by a participating adult. Children 15 to 17 years old can participate alone after their parent has signed the L.L.Bean participant agreement for minors. 

Need help preparing for your next adventure? Visit L.L.Bean Store at Ross Park Mall and ask to speak with an Outdoor Product Specialist. L.L.Bean will fit you with the right clothing and gear for all of life's adventures.

L.L.Bean Store at Ross Park Mall 
1000 Ross Park Mall Drive (Map) 
Pittsburgh, PA  15237 
L.L.Bean Outdoor Discovery Schools 
Website | Meetup | Twitter | Facebook

results.description:
Take whatever cheesy idea you have about magicians and throw it out the window, because Lee Terbosic has seamlessly developed something that will change everything you’ve ever thought about magic. A rare phenomenon in the world of magic, Lee blending his masterful skills in this ancient art form to create illusions that are fresh, exciting and current to today’s audiences. Lee has appeared on NBC's America's Got Talent -- as well as CBS, A&E and TLC, and wowed countless celebrities like Heidi Klum, Gene Simmons, Johnny Depp, Wiz Khalfia and Howard Stern. A national touring performer, Lee has hit the stage at a multitude of diverse venues from coast to coast, entertaining countless corporate audiences, university crowds and for numerous gala events. In 2015 Lee was named MAGICIAN OF THE YEAR by The Association for the Promotion of Campus Activities.

Check out one of the many example videos of Lee's magic

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YBGS0KR3pGg

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0lhg3xCfRCc

So please join us for a late night set featuring laughs and mystifying feats from Pittsburgh's own Lee Terbosic. The evening also includes desserts and a complimentary beverage -- as well as a one-year Partners membership with the Pittsburgh Cultural Trust for new contributors which includes great benefits such as a member discount on tickets to our summer event, Cosmopolitan Pittsburgh as well as invitations to cast parties, presale offers for upcoming shows (PNC Broadway touring shows, various concerts, and other productions), and discounts at Cultural District restaurants.  What a great deal!


TICKETS - To buy your $25 tickets in advance, please go online https://trustarts.culturaldistrict.org/event/10253/cabaret-late-night-set-with-lee-terbosic It only takes a couple minutes to submit the online form, and then you'll get a confirmation email regarding your tickets.  As a reminder, this 1-year Pittsburgh Cultural Trust membership is by household/address so this is important if you're thinking about this offer as a gift or bringing friends/family. Please contact Jenn at the Pittsburgh Cultural Trust if you have any questions for including the membership for others, such as if you could pay for this but give another address for the membership [masked]

For more information on the Pittsburgh Cultural Trust Partner program, please visit http://trustarts.org/support/Individual-Giving/partners-membership

For more information about Lee Terbosic, please visit http://www.leeterbosic.com/

Other Shows/Activities in the Cultural District on Friday, April 22

In case anyone might be doing something before the 10:30 PM Lee Terbosic event, here are some other shows/activities taking place downtown on Friday, April 22:


   a) Gallery Crawl (free, throughout the Cultural District)


   b) The Illusionists - Live from Broadway (at Heinz Hall)

   c) "First Date" (at CLO Cabaret Theater)

   d) "Tru" (at Pittsburgh Public Theater)

   e) Theresa Caputo Live! The Experience (at the Benedum)

   f) "Grease" (Pittsburgh Musical Theater production at Byham Theater)


   g) Musiq Soulchild concert (at August Wilson Center)

For more information about these shows, please visit https://trustarts.culturaldistrict.org/calendar?utf8=%E2%9C%93&utf8=%E2%9C%93&genre=All+Genres&organization_id=&start_date=2016%2F04%2F22&end_date=2016%2F04%2F22&filter[min]=2016-04-12T22%3A54%3A51-05%3A00&filter[max]=2017-10-12+23%3A54%3A51+-0400&filter[current_page]=production

Of course, there are also many great restaurants downtown as well as many other options, such as free live jazz  inside the Fairmont Hotel lobby, live music at NOLA (in Market Square), etc.


Please feel free to post comments below in case others may wish to join you at one of the earlier events on Friday, April 22.


Parking Here is the ParkPGH website with real-time info on downtown parking garage availability http://parkpgh.org where you can also download apps, get garage availability via text messaging, etc. You can also call[masked]-8980.

Stay tuned for updates!!

results.description:
GLOBAL COMMUNITY, OUT-OF-THIS-WORLD INNOVATION

For 48-72 hours across the world, problem solvers like you join us for NASA’s International Space Apps Challenge, one of the largest hackathons in the universe. Empowered by open data, you collaborate with strangers, colleagues, friends, and family to solve perplexing challenges in new and unexpected ways -- from designing an interactive space glove to natural language processing to clean water mapping. Join us on our open data mission, and show us how you innovate.

NOT JUST FOR CODERS

Beginners, students, experts, engineers, makers, artists, storytellers -- Space Apps is for you! We welcome all passionate problem solvers to join our community of innovators. Citizens like you have already created thousands of open-source solutions together through code, data visualizations, hardware and design. How will you make your global impact?

Register: https://2016.spaceappschallenge.org/locations/pittsburgh-pa-usa
results.name: NASA Space Apps Challenge  Weekend Hackathon

results.description: All riders are welcome at our Saturday morning Beginner Ride. The average pace of this ride is 8-12 miles per hour. In other words, nice-n-easy. J The ride starts and ends at our Pittsburgh Performance Bicycle store and lasts approximately one hour. The beginner route includes residential riding and local bike paths, as well as 1 moderately busy, yet approachable intersection that we’ll tackle as a group. The Beginner Ride provides an opportunity to build basic riding skills including: ride with others in a group, ride safely and confidently when vehicles are present, bring the right gear on your ride, shift and brake comfortably and effectively. More experienced riders can attend the Beginner Ride to meet new people and share knowledge with those new to cycling. Rides are weekly, rain or shine. (Thunder cancels.)

The Pittsburgh Model Club (East) is sponsored by the Pittsburgh Chapter of BetterInvesting for the purpose of teaching investment club operations and investment decision-making techniques.  This Model Club focuses on using computerized techniques to screen for potential investments, to analyze stocks of interest, and to manage a stock portfolio.

Anyone can attend as a visitor and is eligible to apply for a membership. Visitors are encouraged to participate in our lively discussions (but only members my vote on investment decisions for the club)

Each member invests between $10 and $100 per month and the club maintains an investment portfolio following BetterInvesting procedures.

Bonjour! This Saturday’s program for French in Action is:

• Beginning (10am-11am) CHAPTER 11

• Intermediate (11am-12pm) CHAPTERs 23 - “A la recherche d’une invitation II"

Textbook we are using now is FRENCH IN ACTION (any edition). I have pdf copies of other materials.

Reminder - be sure to go over videos online before class.

The order of things should be:

• watch video online by yourself = the location is here <http://www.learner.org/resources/series83.html>

 • review lab book exercises (on google drive)

 • read textbook

 • be prepared to answer questions at the end of each chapter (mise en oeuvre)


In class we will devote time to conversation, improvisation, and some grammar points.

results.description:
SIMPLICITY REIGNS!!

I'm scheduling this in April because (according to the tourism office) in the summer months the roads are so crowded. This is also 3 weeks before the Wildflower meet up. I feel 3 weeks apart is sufficient. We should be anxious to get out of the house.

 Please read the entire post. This is a self-guided driving tour. We will meet in Volant at 10 am and decide if anyone wants to go together in the cars. 

Located one hour north of Pittsburgh, the Old Order Amish community of approximately 1,500 people lives in farms that surround the quaint villages of New Wilmington and Volant in the northern section of the county. Fourteen different districts comprise the community. The average church district is comprised of 75 adult members in addition to all of the unbaptized children and young adults. Church officials including a bishop govern each district. Decisions of the officials determine the way of life of the community.

Descendants of Jakob Amman, the Amish have retained much of the same style clothing worn in the Palatine region of Switzerland during the sixteenth century. The plain, but functional garb sets them apart from the worldliness that threatens their existence. The similarity of dress also discourages pride and encourages modesty.

Amish girls and women wear dresses primarily in colors of royal blue, navy blue, black or brown. Reds, pinks, oranges and yellows are prohibited, as are patterned fabrics. One thing is absolute. There are never buttons on the clothing of the Old Order Amish women.

Men and boys wear denim trousers with two large overlapping panels in the front, which button to the waist. The bishop determines the number and size of buttons. Coats and vests are fastened by hook and eyes, never buttons. Suspenders are used to hold up the trousers. Belts are never worn.

The Amish practice homechurching–gathering for Sunday services at various homes. It is a major undertaking to host the preaching service. With the help of family and friends, the house is cleaned and scrubbed from top to bottom. The host family also provides the noon meal for the congregation.

Many of the Amish in Lawrence County are agricultural or dairy farmers; the farms are usually passed from one generation to another. Horses are used to plow the fields. Some Amish subsidize their farm income with woodworking and construction.

Tourists to Lawrence County may travel the back roads on the Amish community and view their way of life. The Amish do not like their faces to be photographed. For a taste of the simpler lifestyle, visit our beautiful Amish Countryside near Volant and New Wilmington. A self-guided tour offers a glimpse into a world devoid of modern chaos. These simple people have retained the lifestyle of their 16th-century ancestors. Their sprawling family farms are testaments to the values they pass on through generations. And please share the road with their buggies!

A brochure providing the tour is available by calling the Lawrence County Tourist Promotion Agency, New Castle, Pennsylvania at[masked]-7599.   Please call that number and get your tour map sent to you. Don't wait too long to call. 

You can also download it and print it from this link. 

http://visitlawrencecounty.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/06/Amish-Drive-Yourself-Tour-map.pdf


We will likely stop after for an appetizer/meal and drink. Of course this is optional. If I have forgotten something, let me know. I'm trying to get these on the schedule early because I have to work one Saturday a month and the days are first come, first serve.


As usual, any suggestions are welcomed.   Rain date would probably be in July.   We'll cross that bridge when we come to it.  :)

Another Free outdoor meet up event!    Yaaaaaa!
results.name: RESCHEDULED ***. AMISH COUNTRYSIDE TOUR  IN LAWRENCE COUNTY

results.description:
We are having another Saturday gaming event at the Giant Market District Express before the April showers make Saturdays a washout for the whole month!  So stop in and see that old drip himself, Redbeard!

Have you met Redbeard out at the South Hills Village location of Barnes and Noble during their product demonstrations in March?  Trust him to teach you some more games? He's ready for you. So bring a game you want to try, or come learn some games that you will more likely find on the shelf at B&N than in the toy aisle at Wal-Mart. The games our group play come from all over the world. We have a group of folks who are usually excited to teach someone a new or a classic game, and we have people who are very game (sorry) to give any games that you may bring a shot. 

Experienced? Inexperienced? In between? Need a little coaching to get through your turn? Ready to give it a shot? Come out and see us! If there is a specific game that you want to try, make a comment below ahead of time, and if someone we know has a copy, we will try to make it happen!

Drop in any time after Noon. People come and go all day. RSVPs are very appreciated, and allow me to know to not cancel the event. But do drop in last minute if that's how life is working out for you. There is no admission to attend. If one person says they are certainly in, that's all I need to make the day worthwhile to keep on the schedule in my book. Hate to sit there with two bags of games like a dope.

There is a rather good selection on food as well. For those who would enjoy beers and especially craft beers, they do have such things on site. Also a Starbucks, but that's not my game. We'll be playing in the dining area. Note that the dining area and food preparation services both shut down at 10 PM. We try to wind things down at 9:30 to make life easier on the Giant Eagle Market District Express Staff.

If you have ideas for venues and towns in which to hold an event in mind, please do contact me. We know there are a lot of towns that hope to game that we are missing good events on the map. We have a lot of assistant organizers, and we're pretty liberal about handing out the duty and title, because all it truly means is you have taken the effort to arrange something, and you should be the contact for any questions about it. We don't need money or a great amount of time from you. Just a willing heart, a face welcoming to all comers, and your enthusiasm is all it really takes. We have games. Let's go make some gamers!

Text me with your questions here on meetup, in a Personal message, or on my cell (724)[masked] .
results.name: Saturday Gaming!  Giant Eagle Market District Express

results.description:
This month we have chosen to read Mrs. Poe by Lynn Cullen not the one from Pittsburgh)

1845: New York City is a sprawling warren of gaslit streets and crowded avenues, bustling with new immigrants and old money, optimism and opportunity, poverty and crime. Edgar Allan Poe’s “The Raven” is all the rage—the success of which a struggling poet like Frances Osgood can only dream. As a mother trying to support two young children after her husband’s cruel betrayal, Frances jumps at the chance to meet the illustrious Mr. Poe at a small literary gathering, if only to help her fledgling career. Although not a great fan of Poe’s writing, she is nonetheless overwhelmed by his magnetic presence—and the surprising revelation that he admires her work.

What follows is a flirtation, then a seduction, then an illicit affair…and with each clandestine encounter, Frances finds herself falling slowly and inexorably under the spell of her mysterious, complicated lover. But when Edgar’s frail wife, Virginia, insists on befriending Frances as well, the relationship becomes as dark and twisted as one of Poe’s tales. And like those gothic heroines whose fates are forever sealed, Frances begins to fear that deceiving Mrs. Poe may be as impossible as cheating death itself…

Even if you choose not to read the book, join us. We always have a good time.

results.description:
The Jane Austen Society of North America, Pittsburgh Chapter Presents:

Mark Wallis as ....


Mr. James Tyson
Master of the Ceremonies
at Bath and Tunbridge Wells

Mark Wallis is the co-founder of Past Pleasures, Ltd., the UK's oldest professional costumed historical interpretation company: http://pastpleasures.co.uk/ The company trains and costumes "first person" interpreters for many major historical sites in England, covering the Battle of Hastings through WWII.

Mark will be appearing as the famous M.C. at Bath in the last quarter of the 18th century, replaced after his retirement by the Mr. King who introduces Mr. Tilney to Miss Morland. He will be taking questions from you--you might enjoy this article as prep: http://www.jasna.org/persuasions/on-line/vol31no1/thompson.html.


Mark's attire will be reproduction, but he will be bringing with him and will talk about some period artifacts, such as a late 18th century traveling case.

After Mark's presentation, some of us will go out for dinner nearby.


Venue: Room 232, Cathedral of Learning, University of Pittsburgh


The second floor of the Cathedral is NOT directly accessible by the main elevators located in the central part of the building. You may use the stairs located at the corners of the building, or take the elevator to 3 and walk down, or take the elevator to 3 and follow the signs to a small, secret elevator (smaller than Mr. Suckling's barouche!) that will take you to 2.

$5 donation requested.
results.name: Attention Jane Austen & English History Fans: Historical Interpreter

results.description:
The 19th annual Art All Night will be held on April 23rd starting at 4pm through April 24th (2016) at 2pm. This year we have a new location, the Arsenal Terminal Building at 39th and Butler Streets in Lawrenceville!
When the doors open at 4pm…

The music begins, the children’s activities start and the parking lots start to fill. In 2015, we had an estimated 15,000 people attend, most of whom visited on Saturday night.

When is the best time to go?

That depends on the atmosphere you are looking for. Saturday night is loud with lots of children’s and adult art activities, bands and the largest crowds. Sunday morning is more peaceful with much smaller crowds. The middle of the night has a whole other vibe to it with lots of local color. Interactive art activities occur throughout the whole event. And then the auction takes place Sunday at noon at the stage area. This is where all the art created by the onsite artists will be sold.

What about children?

Bring them with you! The show is open to everyone. Children’s activities are held from 4 to 8 pm on Saturday and again at 10 am to 2 pm on Sunday next to a youth-friendly section of art. The rest of the show is uncensored. Please keep an eye on your little (and big) ones and do not leave them unattended at the show.
see their website http://www.artallnight.org/wp/
results.name: Art All Night in Lawrenceville

results.description:
Meet 7:15, showtime 7:30 pm. (there is also a 5:15 pm showing)

Music is the beating heart of Mali, but when jihadists took control of northern Mali in 2012, they banned all forms of music. Radio stations were destroyed and instruments burned. Overnight, musicians were forced into hiding or exile where most remain, even now. But rather than lay down their instruments, the musicians fought back, standing up for their cultural heritage and identity. This powerful film tells the story of the separatist’s uprising, reveals rare footage of the jihadists, and follows several musicians as they perform at the first public concert in Timbuktu since the music ban.

Johanna Schwartz | UK | 2015 | 105 min

Note: One of the bands featured in this film, Songhoy Blues, performs at The Warhol on April 12: http://www.warhol.org/responsive/event.aspx?id=27110

Trailer:

https://vimeo.com/153930504
results.name: They Will Have to Kill Us First @ The Harris

results.description:
Time to get ready for the skating season!  Only two short months until our season officially begins!

For those who haven't skated the off season with us before, these are slightly less organized, unpatrolled skated.    What that means is distance and terrain varies.   Most likely there will be a hill or two ... maybe three.    And distance is usually 15-20 miles over about two to two and half hours.    We'll still be looking out for the last skater and regrouping periodically, and including an optional coffee stop mid to end of the skating.       We'll continue, weather permitting (roads dry) straight through until the May 1st start of the season!

results.description:
The Upper St. Clair and Mt. Lebanon Public Libraries have planned a series of three spring walks and talks in April, May and June to encourage our communities to share in the beauty of spring. Both libraries will host each of the three presentations at their location. The presentations are planned to make us more attuned to the birds, flowers and plants that we may encounter on our springtime woodland hikes. Both communities will come together and share the walks which will be led by a nature guide at three different locations in Upper St. Clair and Mt. Lebanon; Bird Park, Boyce Mayview Park and Gilfillan Farm. The first talk of the series “Birds in Your Backyard” with Knox Brown of Wild Birds Unlimited will take place on Monday, April 18th at the Upper St. Clair Library and Thursday, April 21st at the Mt. Lebanon Public Library.

Come and enjoy listening about the fundamentals of bird feeding. It's a great time to learn about the hobby and start enjoying birds in your backyard.

The accompanying walk “Birds in Bird Park” guided by Jim Phillips of Mt. Lebanon Nature Conservancy will take place on Sunday, April 24th from 9:00 a.m.-11:00 a.m. at Bird Park in Mt. Lebanon. Call Mt. Lebanon Public Library at[masked] to register.
results.name: Birds in Bird Park Guided Walk

results.description:
Orienteering is a sport practiced all over the world, but mostly in Scandinavian and East European countries, in which participants are given a specially-designed topographic map and checkpoints to find solely with the use of the map and a compass. It is a form of land navigation, bonding both the mind and the body into an outdoor activity in which natural features and terrain is your playground.

Once a year the Western Pennsylvania Orienteering Club hosts a FREE event to promote the sport and open it to folks that have never tried it before and inviting newbies to try it out. Instruction by volunteers available on site. Compass loaners available on site.

April 24, Carp I shelter, show up anytime between 10:45 and 2 PM. Event closes at 3:30 PM.

Once at the park entrance, look for red-and-white arrow signs. Deer Lakes Workshop
24 April 2016
Preview

ALL PARTICIPANTS must wear appropriate clothing (shoes that cover the feet and long pants). There may be ticks or other biting insects. Using insect repellant is an exceptionally good idea. It is Spring, so it is likely to be somewhat wet or muddy. Beginner Instruction:

There will be two identical sessions, one starting at 11 am, the other starting at 1 pm. In each session, there will be instruction on map reading, simple use of the compass (orienting the map) and how an orienteering course works. If time allows, there may be additional instruction topics. There will also be an exercise in which participants can put what they have learned into practice. Each session will last approximately 90 minutes. Compasses will be loaned to those who do not have them. Intermediate Instruction:

There will be a single session that starts at 12 noon and will last 1 ½ to 2 hours. The focus will be on off-trail navigation (following a bearing) and keeping track of distance, combined with terrain association. Various navigational and map handling tips will be introduced. Instruction will be done through a series of exercises that go around a short orienteering course, much of it off trail. Compasses will be loaned to those who do not have them. Advanced Exercises:

There will be three types of exercises to choose from. Each involves doing a short orienteering course in one way or another. The courses are kept short to allow participants to do more than one exercise: starting on an exercise may be done between 11 am and 2:30 pm. Donut-Hole-O

Activity: Given a map that has been erased for some distance surrounding a control location, make your way around a short cross-country orienteering course. Only the control circle appears in the erased area. There are no control descriptions but control flags are placed on standard orienteering features at the center of the control circles. Control flag numbers are shown, in sequence, on the map. Beware, there are controls from other courses nearby.

Purpose: To practice choosing attack points, then practice using precise navigation from the attack point to the control location. Pathless-O Activity: Find the controls in a normal cross-country orienteering course using a map on which trails and possibly other black features have been removed. If you are thinking of doing more than one exercise, do this one first - the other exercises will show the trails, roads, etc. which would partly defeat the purpose of this exercise.

Purpose: To practice using contours and vegetation features in terrain association; also to practice using the compass and making distance measurements. Corridor-O Activity: Follow the serpentine corridor counterclockwise from the start and find the controls which are placed on standard orienteering features at or near the center of the corridor. Some controls from other courses are also in the middle of the corridor. The corridor is about 75 m in width; only the map inside the corridor is shown. The control descriptions list only the control flag numbers in sequence order. Purpose: To practice precise terrain association and navigation.
results.name: map and compass orienteering at Deer Lakes park

results.description:
From Goodreads:

"Sick of deeply personal accounts written in the first person? Seeking an exciting, interactive read that puts the “u” back in “aUtobiography”? Then look no further than Neil Patrick Harris: Choose Your Own Autobiography! In this revolutionary, Joycean experiment in light celebrity narrative, actor/personality/carbon-based life-form Neil Patrick Harris lets you, the reader, live his life. You will be born in New Mexico. You will get your big break at an acting camp. You will get into a bizarre confrontation outside a nightclub with actor Scott Caan. Even better, at each critical juncture of your life, you will choose how to proceed. You will decide whether to try out for Doogie Howser, M.D. You will decide whether to spend years struggling with your sexuality. You will decide what kind of caviar you want to eat on board Elton John’s yacht.

Choose correctly and you’ll find fame, fortune, and true love. Choose incorrectly and you’ll find misery, heartbreak, and a hideous death by piranhas. All this, plus magic tricks, cocktail recipes, embarrassing pictures from your time as a child actor, and even a closing song. Yes, if you buy one book this year, congratulations on being above the American average, but make that book Neil Patrick Harris: Choose Your Own Autobiography!"
results.name: Choose Your Own Autobiography by Neil Patrick Harris

Please sign up if you're planning on playing and bring your favorite games!  Newbies are very welcome.  We have some great teachers to help you get started on your gaming adventure.  Let us know when you sign up what game(s) you'll be bringing.  On Sundays there is plenty of free parking on the side streets and even right on Murray.  Crazy Mocha serves great coffee, specialty drinks, snacks and pastries.  They do allow us to bring food in if we take our trash with us. We usually play all day, break for dinner around 6:00, then it's back to gaming until everybody poops out. 

Incidentally, many of our regular players no longer bother to sign up (but I really wish they would!), so if it looks like only  one or two people are coming, there could actually be quite a few more.  Remember, I will always cancel a game Meetup if we aren't gaming that day, so you won't be sitting there all by yourself waiting for a friend.    And please, remember to change your rsvp to no if you can't make it that day!

Indira Corales Latin Music performs a wide spectrum of Latin American music, from smooth-sounding Spanish ballads and boleros, to upbeat cha-cha-chá and son. The ensemble plays tunes that are known worldwide, such as "Bésame Mucho", "Sway" ("¿Quién será?"), and "Guantanamera".

As a native of Chile, Indira Corales performs in Spanish. Indira has been the leading voice of salsa music in Pittsburgh for over fifteen years as the frontperson for Azúcar Latin Dance band.

Indira Corales Latin Music is a fresh sounding ensemble that creates an entertaining mixture of jazz and the traditional folkloric music of Latin America here at the Library!

Free.  All ages.

results.description:
TROIS SOUVENIRS DE MA JEUNESSE/My Golden Days
Recalling the best of Francois Truffaut, this evocative portrait of youth begins with a middle-aged anthropologist reflecting on his life. Through a series of flashbacks we see his early years as well as his life-changing student years, including a trip to the USSR where he meets a young Russian he considers a phantom twin. He remembers University life, and his shifting circle of friends. But most of all he remembers Esther, the beautiful, rude, love of his life. Premiered in the Directors’ Fortnight at Cannes. With subtitles.
*Le film commence à 5h15, mais je serai à la porte vers 5h00.

Arnaud Desplechin | France | 2015 | 123 min http://www.magpictures.com/myGoldenDays/

results.description:
AITP PITTSBURGH APRIL 25TH DINNER MEETING AT SILVIONI’S

It’s Never too Early or Late to Start Thinking about Retirement
Roy Laux

Roy will focus on the changing landscape on investing over the years with a concentration on the retirement issue. He will discuss the advantages of having time work for us from students who land their first job, to individuals who are getting ready to retire, to those who are retired. He will examine the wisdom of tax deferred and tax free plans, all with a retirement focus.

Everyone who attends this meeting will leave with something new to consider no matter where they are in the retirement cycle.

ROY LAUX began his career as a registered representative in 1984 with New York Life and established the Synergy Group in 1988, where he continues to serve as president. Specializing in retirement planning for over 30 years, he helps retirees and individuals near retirement meet more of their financial goals and dreams. His practice is focused on securing independent retirements for his clients by creating predictable income plans, protecting retirement assets, and mitigating the cost of long term care. He maintains his securities license and his Pennsylvania Life, Health and Accident insurance license. Roy has resided in Elizabeth Township since 1979 with his beautiful wife, Cindy, who he married in 1972. He and Cindy have two adult children. Roy currently serves as the President of Champion Christian School Board. He also has served in various capacities on the board at the First Evangelical Free Church of McKeesport over the past 20 years and several nonprofit charity groups. He feels his greatest remaining opportunity in life is to help model his eight grandchildren to be caring. God-loving citizens of this great nation.

Synergy Financial Services is a full-service financial firm based out of McKeesport, Pa. Synergy has continued to thrive as a family owned and operated business representing many local clients across the Western Pennsylvania area. Synergy truly operates as a ‘family’ working to meet the financial needs not only of our valued clients but the families of our clients as well. Along with the family employees, Synergy has networked with others close to us including financial professionals with different areas of focus, attorneys, and CPAs to care for our family of clients from every avenue.

Synergy is well known on many radio stations as “Laux on Your Retirement”. Weekly on the radio: WJAC 1320 AM (Saturday from 8-9 am), WORD Christian talk – FM 101.5 (Saturdays from 10-11 am), 73 WPIT (Saturdays from 11 am-Noon), KQV AM1410 (Saturdays from 3-4 pm), FAN Pittsburgh Sport Radio 93.7 FM (Saturdays from 8-9 am) and 1480 WCNS Oldies (Saturdays from 10-11 am).

Silvioni’s Restaurant (North Hills)
2125 Babcock Blvd

results.description:
In Accidental Saints, New York Times bestselling author Nadia Bolz-Weber invites readers into a surprising encounter with what she calls “a religious but not-so-spiritual life.” Tattooed, angry, and profane, this former standup comic turned pastor stubbornly, sometimes hilariously, resists the God she feels called to serve. But God keeps showing up in the least likely of people—a church-loving agnostic, a drag queen, a felonious Bishop, and a gun-toting member of the NRA.

As she lives and worships alongside these “accidental saints,” Nadia is swept into firsthand encounters with grace—a gift that often feels less like being wrapped in a warm blanket and more like being hit by a blunt instrument. But by this grace, people are transformed in ways they couldn’t have been on their own.

"Nadia Bolz-Weber's new book is even tougher, sharper and sweeter than 


Pastrix:

 in painfully honest stories, she pulls back the curtains of religious life to show how church—the actual, living body of God—is created among us.  This is a book for everyone who yearns to be made new."


-Sara Miles, author of Take This Bread and City of God
